author: {'steamid': '76561198346109096', 'num_games_owned': 1749, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1572335900}
review:
[b]I MADE IT WORK WITH WINDOWS 7 PROFESSIONAL!--Finally![/b]  
July 15, it worked.  Then for a while, all I got is "Play>Your Drivers May be Out of Date. Check for Updates."  When I clicked play, it closed the launcher and crashed.  This was annoying because the game worked in July, when i checked it (to make sure it worked on my PC) after buying it.

Also, when i installed the game and ran it for the first time, it broke Comodo Firewall (Free) by loading, going to a black screen, and never doing anything.  I had to crash the PC, and after that Comodo doesn't work and has been replaced.  (M:TW worked fine after that.)

The fact that it won't run was really a shame, because I've been recommended this game by a close friend with similar gaming tastes, and thought the game looked good.  Plus, the price was right, but it's been to long to return it at this point. 

[b][u]DO NOT RUN IF YOU USE COMODO FIREWALL![/u][/b]

I was able to use Perdiccas's "Fixing Crashes" Guide [url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=865714593[/url] to get MTW-GE to run.  

I verified (~14k files bad), re-verified (two files gone bad), set the exe to run in compatability mode for Vista SP2 and Run as Admin. (It still crashed).  
[b][u]What made it work was launching the game with my screen resolution set to 1024x768.[/u][/b]  
I maybe had to alt-tab into the game. I don't need to run it in Compatability Mode or as Admin as long as I open it with the screen resolution at 1024x768.  

I changed all the game graphics to run in 1920x1080, and I can alt-tab to desktop and back in safely.  
I alt-tabbed to desktop and set the monitor to 1920x1080 and the game works well, but I think I need to start the game with the desktop set to 1024x768.  

On the other hand, I just fought a quick battle as Italians (me) vs French and the end result was French=450ish dead, 890 lost Italian 900 dead, 450 lost--but I won. Somehow. :)

It looks good, but it doesn't start easily, so my final score is: 4.5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069159152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2420, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1506659364}
review:
This is the second game produced in the Total War series. You can see its age in some ways. Perhaps most importantly, this is the game just before the break-out hit of Rome: Total War. The mechanics that Total War games are famous for... had not yet been fully created and implimented. In this game, moving into a province will automatically incite a battle at the end of the turn, so there is not slow movement of multiple armies to bury a foe under... or to be buried under.

That said, you can see some of the mechanics beginning to take shape. And it still had good play. Just don't expect it to be "modern". And maybe get it when it is on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100533864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1506368848}
review: I thought this was going to be an accurate medieval war battle game, but if I remember history class correctly, people from medieval times didn’t stop in the middle of conquering Europe because “medieval total war stopped working”.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007362946', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 254, 'last_played': 1468071976}
review:
Like Shogun 1, this game keeps crashing randomly for me.  The program just terminates and it kicks me to the desktop as if I was never playing anything.  I can't figure out why it does this, but as long as it does this review will stay negative.

As for the game itself, it's the second Total War game, and it really feels like it.  While it's not a bad game, it still hasn't aged all that well.  There are some good aspects, like the awesome soundtrack and being able to pick your starting era (allowing you to play factions that aren't in any other Total War game like the Abbasid Caliphate).  It also comes with the Viking Invasion expansion, which has you playing in Dark Ages Britain (again, another time that no other Total War game has visited).  

For curiosity's sake, Medieval 1 is fun to play, but unless you're super nostaligic for this game you'll probably wish you were playing one of the later entries.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027980843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7692, 'last_played': 1690077148}
review:
Classic game. This title & Shogun: TW1 had originally gotten me into the Total War series and I never looked back. Previously, back then, I had the disc version, but it was more than worth it to repurchase on Steam especially at such a low price. The TW gameplay has evolved much over the years, however, going back to this style never gets old. I would highly recommend this game for seasoned TW & strategy gamers or those new to the series altogether.

P.S. Unfortunately many people, including myself, have had issues causing the Steam version to crash due to varying reasons. Thankfully there are multiple community threads & guides relating to these issues, from the most complicated all the way to those only requiring a change in screen resolution. So if you find yourself having these types of issues I would very much recommend to read through the threads as they can be incredibly helpful for you as they were for me.

Here is one thread which was helpful for me. It's an older one, so i recommend skipping to the later pages to see the recent discussions & issues people have had which would likely be most relevant for everyone.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/345260/discussions/0/523890681406857588/?tscn=1495774680

author: {'steamid': '76561198200702903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 18292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10612, 'last_played': 1580328225}

author: {'steamid': '76561197960819836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 45114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2305, 'last_played': 1585976081}
review:
I've played this game since 2002 and am still playing it today thanks to this Steam version purchase. This lived on my laptop for more than a decade when it was in CD version. I've played Shotun 1 and Shogun 2 and MTW2 as well. Why do I still like this version after all these years? The loading times for everything, the battles and the strategic map are all FAST. Its a beer and pretzels strategy and tactics game that I can run w/o worrying about load times. Its deep enough to entertain me for hours on end. I get so much satisfaction from how smooth the game runs even on low spec machines. Sure its pixelated as hell but isn't low spec pixels all the rage w/ them indie games nowadays? 

Its not buggy. It runs on my Windows 10 laptop. Strangely enough tho I cant get the game to launch on this Windows 7 gaming rig of mine. No problem. A laptop is best for this game. 

If you miss this game, buy it. If you're new to the TW series, give it a shot. You won't regret it. 

Now I'm off to invade the French again. lol

author: {'steamid': '76561198079766519', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1645648766}

author: {'steamid': '76561198022825975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2654, 'last_played': 1660421335}
review:
Excellent jeu, avec sa phase stratégique sur carte et ses combats tactiques sur le terrain, au plus près des soldats... Ajoutez une dose d'économie, de politique, d'assassinats, et vous obtenez un jeu prenant à tous les niveaux. J'ai passé beaucoup d'heures sur ce jeu chronophage. Je l'ai racheté sur Steam, dans cette version "collector"...

Mais le jeu n'a fonctionné que quelques semaines. Une mise à jour windows ou nVidia (on ne sait plus trop...) et le jeu ne démarre plus du tout. Mes écrans clignotent 5 secondes, apparemment il y a un problème de résolution, et puis windows affiche fièrement : "Medieval Total War a cessé de fonctionner..." avant même la cinématique du début... Un scandale quand on adore ce jeu ! 

On va dans des forums mais on apprend rien, on requiert l'assistance Steam pour un patch éventuel mais on est redirigé dare dare vers le développeur officiel... A quoi bon puisque ce sift a été développé en 2002 ??? Un beau gâchis, vraiment !

Modifications janvier 2018 : Il est possible de faire tourner le jeu (WINDOWS 7), procédez comme suit :
- Effacer le contenu du répertoire des sauvegarde dans Program files (X86)/Steam/SteamApps/Common/Total War Medieval 1 Gold/Savegames (videz tous les fichiers vous perdrez vos éventuelles sauvegardes)
- Dans le répertoire MedievalTotalWar cherchez Medieval_TW.exe, clic droit et propriétés. Onglet "compatibilité" cochez "Exécuter ce programme..." dans le menu déroulant, sélectionnez "Windows XP (Service Pack 3)", juste en dessous, cochez les trois options qui commencent par "Désactiver..." enfin, cochez encore en dessous "Exécuter en tant qu'administrateur". Clic sur Appliquer puis OK. De retour dans le répertoire "Total War Medieval 1 Gold" clic droit sur le fichier "Miedeval_TW.exe" puis "Ouvrir".

Attention, toutefois, le jeu est instable. Il déteste, notamment, les retours windows en cours de partie ! En outre, le temps passé sur le jeu ne sera pas enregistré dans Steam puisqu'on ne passe pas par l'interface pour jouer... Bon jeu !

author: {'steamid': '76561197969749884', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 1422, 'playtime_forever': 319016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14940, 'last_played': 1556083153}
review:
I have a lot of fond memories towards the first Medieval title which ended up with me replaying it once more with close to all factions. It definitely doesn't deserve all the mixed reviews based on compatibility issues with Win10. I'm using Win10 myself and I might have had the occasional crash but it was nowhere as drastic as reviews here might suggest. Apart from the technical side, Medieval is one of the, if not actually the most beloved game of the entire Total War series to many.

By today's standards I'm personally missing things like army stances, agent actions, general abilities and traits, unit abilities and more formation options, but in its core, Medieval was brilliantly balanced without all these newer generation options and it still plays flawlessly fluent today regarding its timeless mechanics.

On the graphical side it hasn't aged too well, but even with newer titles in the series coming close to eye candy, Total War was never about visual appeal in the first place, but about tactical acuity and planning long military campaigns dozens of turns into the future. It looks abysmal in the first 30 minutes of playing, but it is able to engulf a players consciousness just the way it did 15 years ago.

I personally can and will recommend any Total War title, as I have played and loved all of them, but Medieval will always have a special place in my heart as it was the first Total War I played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056335152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 223344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 4481, 'playtime_at_review': 9385, 'last_played': 1712439668}
review:
This is a great game which I have been playing (off and on) for years, and have got pretty good at it. I bought it on Steam a few months back as my Windows 8 laptop wouldn't run or install it. 
The only problem I have with it  is that it doesn't work properly. 
As noted by other players it 'hangs' or crashes at certain points or as a reaction to certain activities. I was led to believe this was due to the Autosave and quicksave functions, so have tried to play the game without using these. Annoying but not crippling. However I still get crashes when certain things are attempted, particularly multiple 'stack' attacks against provinces held by multiple stacks/armies. This has led me to a very defensive style of play, if I attack, the game will crash, if I wait for them to attack me, it won't. (I still does sometimes though.) This makes the 'world domination' objective rather difficult. 
Steam are aware of this and have been some time and yet still have not published a patch to remedy the issue. As it stands I feel like I have been sold unmerchantable goods.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081012303', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1550739797}
review:
~The Red pill has dropped on my childhood but that still doesn't take anything away.~

The first time I played medieval total war, being that little f*cker who loved history and wars, this absoetely BLOWED ME AWAY! Like a kid with toys, I could comjure up my own little battles, my own little secnarios, my own little stories in this medieaval world with a quirky chess like board acting as the map to which I would move my chess like army pieces as I slowly take over the world, piece by piece. There is literally no other franchise you can do that in and that is the reason why I absoelty love Creative Assembly.

But after many years down the line of playing pretty much every Total War to date, coming back to this one after many years was an eye opener. The battles to me as a kid, they looked flipping ULTRA REALISTIC and like a matrix red pill moment, I realised they were just an illusion of 2D sprites rotated and turned to look 3D. But that didn't make me sad but amazed and buoyant for how far this franchise has come. In all honesty, I would only recommened it to the hardcore total war fans who havent played this one yet, old school strategy euthantists or just collectionists who want an classic in their libary.

Regarding crashing, I have had no issues with the digital verison so far of yet even though my disc version doesnt work anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018025575', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 685, 'last_played': 1526135606}

author: {'steamid': '76561198067524553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1500562051}
review:
Bought this game a while back because I lost the original disks ages ago. Got this when it was new and it was fantastic. When compared to the original Shogun which had very little unit diversity, Medieval was choc a block full of new unit types and with that new stratagies and tactics. Each nations start was a different game (for the most part, French and English had very similar starting units) and adjustments to the different quality of similar types of troops lent it's way towards planning battles differently.

 Comparing it to modern titles in the series would be pointless, the campaign map works differently to anything from Rome onwards and sea battles are in the same boat but this was a huge step in the right direction for the franchise. When it came out there was nothing like it, forming up my Almohad urban militia with Nubian spearmen in the center and Gholam cavalry in reserve with skirmishers out front to draw fire and the enemy charge inwards or using my Spanish Jinetes to harass infantry moving about with missile or cavalry support or dealing with the Popes complaints and threats of excomunication as a Christian faction or crusades as a Muslim faction (seriously that guy would get on my nerves no matter who I played) this game HAS so much, not just had so much.

 It's still a great game but if you can't handle what is now low end graphics than don't bother, but if justifying your expensive GFX card isn't important to you then this game is fantastic fun for its price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049020554', 'num_games_owned': 4131, 'num_reviews': 374, 'playtime_forever': 752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 696, 'last_played': 1498924710}
review:
For such an old game (the second in the Total War series), Medieval Total War still has its attractiveness.

The point of this game is similar to most other Total War games: take everything over and expand your empire (or at least that's the way I play my Total War games). The graphics for Medieval are old and outdated (as expected of a game this old), and they actually resemble Shogun 1 a bit. The gameplay is very similar to Shogun 1 as well, but it takes place in Medieval Europe. You can build buildings and units in each place, with certain buildings granting extra money, perks, or unit building capabilities. Once you gather an army, you can engage in an RTS battle or just choose to autoresolve the battle (I autoresolved most of the time cuz I'm lazy). There are four scenarios I could play: Vikings, Early Stage Europe, Mid Stage Europe, and Late Stage Europe. I chose Early Stage Europe and the Danes (since they started off as just one little fort). I continued to conquer half of Europe and expanded my small Danish Empire to be larger than all the rest of the countries combined. However, the game started to get glitch later on and it kept crashing every time I wanted to end turn.

Overall, Medieval 1 is better than Shogun 1, though very similar, but can be rather entertaining to play as a whole.

Rating: 6.1/10
Recommend Price: $2.99 or below

review:
Gioco del 2002 ma ancora eccezionale.
Ovviamente la parte strategica soffre di qualche limite (come la diplomazia, pressochè irrilevante) ma nel complesso è un titolo che si difende bene anche oggi. Ho giocato a qualcuno dei Total War seguenti, ma nessuno mi ha coinvolto come questo.

I crash purtroppo ci sono sempre stati; è possibile limitarli regolando la risoluzione (tipo 1200x800 o simili) e disattivando il salvataggio automatico.

Un'ultima cosa; nella descrizione è indicato che l'italiano non è disponibile, ma io l'ho installato e ci sto giocando in tale lingua...

author: {'steamid': '76561198021806833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 734, 'last_played': 1559865398}
review:
I was worried about the crashes people have been reporting, but It's been years since I've played this and nostalgia got to me. Since the steam summer sale knocked it down to $2.49 I bought it. It immediately crashed to desktop two times in a row. I didn't even get to the opening. I hit play, a black screen popped up, and then it would crash.

After I updated my drivers the issue seems to have been fixed. I've spent a fair amount of time in game now without any more crashes.

If you played this a ton back in the day, go ahead and buy it. Now I just need a windows 10 version of shogun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979913660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 4475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1503, 'playtime_at_review': 2952, 'last_played': 1711766950}
review:
When I first tried Shogun 1 at a friend's house in 2000 I had fun but I still had no idea how to play it. I considered the game to be for adults and thought I wouldn't be able to learn how to play properly. This would turn out to be true since in 2013 I tried Rome 2 and couldn't make heads or tails out of the gameplay and I had to abandon it. I have now resolved to play through the entire series in order to fully grasp how to play the Total War games and it wasn't until I had clocked 50 hours in both Shogun 1 and this game that I truly began to fully understand how to manage my armies, provinces and conquests.

This game is a great deal more complicated than Shogun 1 but once I started to understand all the mechanics properly I began to see the matrix. I have learned all I can from these two games now and it's time to move on to Rome 1. I can't wait to see what the rest of the series has in store.

Something very interesting I noticed while playing is that one particular piece of music, entitled "European Summer", is completely identical to "The Fields of Ard Skellig" from The Witcher 3. I thought that was nice since I really like the song.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073447286', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 7286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1557696218}
review:
This game is really fun.  But there is a serious issue with the STEAM version.  It just does not work.  On Windows 10 it will freeze up on you within an hour.  On Windows 7 it will go for about two.  This might seem survivable but the freezes are permanent in your game.  Eg, going back to an earlier save and playing will get you back to the turn it froze and no further.

In effect, the game is simply unplayable in its current form.  I will happily give this game a huge thumbs up once this issue is fixed, but until then, save yourself the frustration and don’t buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079546564', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1695257180}
review:
One of my all time favorite games from my youth. I wanted to leave a positive review, but that's not possible. The game crashes constantly in the late game with large battles.

I tried all the little tips and tricks in the other reviews, but it doesn't prevent a large clash from causing a crash. I even tried saving every turn and trying to work around large battles, but it becomes nearly impossible when facing off with a superpower rival.

Save your money, buy Roma Total War.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087761383', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 7890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5489, 'last_played': 1647366835}
review:
Sayfalar dolusu açıklama veya rehber niteliğinde bir yorum beklemeyin.. Açık ve net, görüntü kalitesi kötü. Oyunun çıkış tarihi göz önüne alınırsa görüntü kalitesi herhangi bir önem arz etmiyor.. Oyun çocukluğumdan beri severek oynadığım bir oyun. 100 lerce saat oynamış olan arkadaşları, yorumları inceleyerek görebilirsiniz.. Tereddüt etmeyin. indirime giridiği an kaçırmayın. Siz onu hatırladıkça daha fazla eğleneceksiniz..

NOT(SAVE-CRASH PROBLEM)[SOLVED]: Oyunu zevkle oynayıpta kaydederken (save) oyun çöküyorsa (crash) ve windows 8.1 kullanıcısıysanız benim gibi, oyunu çalıştıran dosyayı (Medieval_TW.exe) bulup sağ tıklayıp çıkan menüde özelliklere tıkladığınızda, uyumluluk tabında uyumluluk moduna tik koyup windows 7 yi seçip tamam diyerek pencereyi kapayın. Okuduğum çözümlerden benim için sorunu gideren bu oldu.

İyi eğlenceler...

author: {'steamid': '76561198080382954', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1514, 'last_played': 1505510676}
review: My favorite game of all times. Most bad reviews are because of the CRASH that happens when you use Autosave and Quicksave and wrong resolution. 1.Disable Autosave by opening options next to minimap,2. Dont use quicksave. 3. In options -change resolution to third from right- 1200X1095 (something like that). Graphics are outdated but gameplay and Medieval feel is awesome. New total war games are too complicated for casual player-this one is perfect. I just destroyed Hungarian dynasty with 1 shot from catapult.  :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561197984782430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1494532358}
review:
Since I saw this question a couple of times I'd like to start with:

!Steam Version Runs on Windows 10!


If you played this as an Adolecent, like I did, you might get some nostalgia and want to play it again. Since I couldnt get my Box Version to Work I bought it here for a couple of Euros in a sale and must say: It didnt age well.

The Battles are simply unplayable by todays standards, not just by Graphics but also Sound, UI and Controls do not hold up. 
The Mapplay is incredibly easy, the AI too passive, building up becomes Work and again, the Controls and UI just feel aged.

Now for the tiny amount of money it costs rght now you might get like one night from it, and this Steam Version does run for me without problem on Windows 10 so I will give a thumbs up for getting it working again, but if youre looking for actual gameplay you should get something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198353402449', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 11131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 858, 'last_played': 1651605357}
review:
My favorite pc game of all time, finally in a format that works on WIndows 10. The only crash I encountered was fixed by going into options and maxing out the resolution. You can make quicksaves by pressing ctrl+S and highlight your province loyalty by holding down shift. twcenter.net and forums.totalwar.org host some great mods, I recommend the XL mod with the Tyberius addons. Here are some cheats.
`.deadringer.` (<-lots of money) `.badgerbunny.' (<-unlock buildings/units) `.matteosartori.` (<-full map) `.conan.`(<-become rebels) `.worksundays.` (<-buildings done in one turn) `.unfreeze.` (prince born next turn)

author: {'steamid': '76561198333232441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 17015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2046, 'last_played': 1704379111}
review:
A great mix of combat and empire building, from the Viking invasion which ends at 1066, through the Medieval era, and the Golden Hoard invasion from the East. A few bugs and crashes, as with all games, but a great time waster from the Total War team. It is hard work, but routing an enemy twice your size is pure joy.

One tip for you, marry off your princesses to your Generals and keep your disloyal Princes seperate from your Armies, or based with your King.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979296136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3655, 'last_played': 1652455105}
review:
Great game, that is all I can say.
I know this game had a lot of issues for the users when it got released on steam, CTD:s for the most part. I bought the game by the release and could never play it properly, was almost giving it up and started to ask for a refund. Instead I gave up this game for a while (like 2 years or something) and damn I was surprised the next time I was playing it without any problems. A patch from the autumn 2015 fixed my issue with the CTD and I can now play like never before ;).

I am using Win 7 64 bit and cannot speak for rest of people that taken the next step to (yuk!) win 10....

author: {'steamid': '76561198032300921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1588987284}
review: Totalwar serisinin açık ara en iyi oyunu benim için. Yüzlerce saatimi harcamıştım bu oyuna ilk çıktığı zamanlarda. author: {'steamid': '76561198090073298', 'num_games_owned': 2578, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 14378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14101, 'last_played': 1642013784}
review:
This is one of the games that keeps me coming back to play it over the years. Released on Steam long after Medieval II, this game has better medieval immersion than its sequel. This is because of small things like unique historical provincial title (Count of Anjou, Prince of Antioch, etc), Roman numerals after reigning monarch's name (Pope Urban II, King Henry V), the granting offices of Marshal, Constable, etc to the monarch's vassals. They disappear in Medieval II. 

You'll rarely find yourself have nobody to grant the governorship of a province of yours to. You can appoint any unit commander to become one. In Medieval II, only generals and adult male royal family members who can and they're often numbered less than the province you own. There are random appearance of general available for adoption to your family if you have more provinces than your generals. This is by chance and you can't have a governor for every province you own anytime you want.

This game is also more challenging than M2TW. One of the reasons is the unit control in battle. Controlling is better in M2TW. If you manually control a missile unit engaging enemy unit in skirmish, constantly double clicking to run away when enemy getting closes, your unit would eventually rout and won't be recoverable. The game consider that unit commander is a coward. You can't rely on the game's skirmish mode at certain situations. This is true for both MTW and M2TW.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998043856', 'num_games_owned': 1178, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1543270401}
review: I think this is the best Total War game produced, though it have some little niggles here and there, especially in the real time battles. What sets it apart from other TW games that came after it, in my opinion, is the grand strategy aspect of the game. Although graphics is dated, especially in the real time battles, this is an excellent game to waste hundreds and hundreds of hours on. Highly recommended for any strategy game fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030897260', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1644438138}
review:
Одна из тройки игр, из за которой просил купить комп в далеком 2003.
Шедевр, который открыл для меня мир пошаговых стратегий, наравне с Civilization III.
Жаль, с оконным режимом туго,а так бы почаще отыгрывал в нее. Для новых игроков врятли будет интересна так же, как для старых олдскульщиков серии TW. Просто игра детства.

review: When I entered into the PC Game World, this one was one of the first games I bought, just because it was about Medieval Age. You could win by conquest or by achievements. author: {'steamid': '76561197991513945', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1488835166}
review:
Rome первый, второй. Empire. Да что вы понимаете. Попробуйте тут отбиться от викингов саксами, когда тебя давят ирландцы. 
Пошаговая мировая карта, и масштабная тактическая, вот такой Total war я полюбил. Да спрайты сейчас выглядят странно, но играть до сих пор приятно. А музыка победы викингов увеличивает приток тестестерона минимум на 10 %.

review: I'm not sure what all it is about this game above all the other Total War games that brings me back so consistently. I like having a "Risk-like" map. That is certainly one thing. Also not having to futz with army movement. It is just fun to play. It is the happy marriage of a boardgame and computer game. Add in some of the mods, and you have a winner.

author: {'steamid': '76561198260411551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 856, 'last_played': 1698583545}

author: {'steamid': '76561197989968007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 39831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17906, 'last_played': 1693615695}
review:
If I were stranded on a desert island, but inexplicably provided with a gaming PC and allowed only a single game, this would certainly be it. A lot of titles have come and gone over my life, but there is something magical about this game that maintains a hold over me, even now.

Fans familiar with the franchise will recognise the game's format. At its heart, it's a turn based strategy game, composed of two arenas. 

In the first, you pore over the campaign map to manage your provinces, generals and armies on the macroscopic level. You control your economy by tweaking taxes, maintaining a trade network and constructing improvements to your provinces. You recruit troops and agents to fight for supremacy through martial power or subterfuge. You plot, scheme and strategise to guide your faction to victory. 

In the second, where your armies meet those of your enemies, you fight on the battle map. Here, you enjoy microscopic control of your units, making careful use of a variety of troop types to defeat enemy armies. 

The gameplay is deep, thoughtful, enjoyable and memorable. Indeed, whilst newer TW games look shinier, their gameplay does not reach the same depths. The sheer scope of ways to play is unmatched. Moreover, the simpler campaign map is much easier for the AI to handle, resulting in genuinely rewarding and complex campaigns.

The game also triumphs in its smaller touches like the texture of notification parchments, the gentle soundtrack, the emerging personalities of generals, the wealth of historical information. 

But my favourite feature, the one that dwarfs all others, is the replayability. Every campaign is different. Sometimes you'll see the AI perform spectacularly with one faction, only to see it destroyed swiftly in the next campaign that you play. Plus, there are multiple periods in which to play, and so many strategies. 

For the belligerent, one can focus on martial power and grind enemies into the dust. For the shrewd, one can exercise soft power by hoarding riches, then bribing enemies and relying on mercenaries. For the underhanded, one can employ a variety of agents, be they assassins, spies or diplomats. Or you can mix all three!

Furthermore, every campaign is itself a wonderful journey. Every nuance contributes to the immersion. A faction rejects my alliance? I'll remember that when they leave their rich provinces poorly defended. Former master general becomes a violent drunkard with waning loyalty? I can assassinate him, frame him for treason, put him on trial for heresy or cart him off to govern a province far away. King is weak and ineffectual, rapidly losing influence over his generals? Let's do everything to stir up disloyalty and simply support the rebellion in the ensuing civil war, quietly removing a useless leader and a minority of misguided loyalists.

In this way, each campaign tells a story, much like the history of any nation. Winning a campaign is not just about the victory itself, but about telling a story fecund with the brutality, avarice and intrigue of the Medieval world.  

So, whenever I jump into a new campaign, I am reminded of these previous games; every faction is held accountable, in my own mind, for its betrayals and underhanded moves in previous campaigns; every province has a memory that makes me smile.

And every campaign is a new challenge, a new story.

Sure, the game has its flaws. The battle map looks horribly dated and the later games improved heavily upon this, particularly with the siege features. But the game holds up beautifully well across the board and contains far more depth on the macroscopic level than supposed sequels.

Why is it doing badly on Steam? Well, lots of people are having crashes. There are fixes out there, but maybe it's not working for everyone. It's a shame really, but I wrote this review to tell people that the game is enchanting and that they should not be perturbed by reports of a few crashes. Patches have come; fixes are known. Indeed, I love this game so much, I wrote an extensive crash fixing guide for the community. 

To sum up, fans of the franchise who came late, or strategy veterans looking for a new challenge, I implore you to try this game! It is a wonderful experience and a triumph of video gaming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007380790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1611, 'last_played': 1467307023}
review:
The only Total War game I ever really enjoyed, after this ones they made added too much micro management of cities, provinces and people.

The game is now outdated and looks it, but the game play and combat is more fun than any of the sequals.
I know a lot of people myself included experience a lot of crashes to desktop, but after a quick google search there is a solution for most people, turn down the resolution from max (or something like that) and the crashes stop....at least they did for me and a lot of other people.

So if you feel nostalgic and want to play a total war game for a reasonable price, without having to micro manage too much then give it another go, it may bring back happy memories, but at the very least it won't annoy you like all the sequals do.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197973159704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 14316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3193, 'last_played': 1570299045}
review:
This was the best stratagy and battle field game around when it came out. I had a few crashes when I started this new game but I save constantly so no major problems.
When I got this game in 2002 or whenever it came out it had a map and troop/building tree sheet that came with it so you could see what was availible/unlocks as you pass through the different ages, that helped alot.

Easy brigde battles, Byzantine Varargian guards, English Longbowmen and Bill men, Swiss pikes, the music, Just AWESOME.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127927516', 'num_games_owned': 537, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 5452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1671624869}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198099637590', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1700583230}
review:
Alright, fam, so first of all. I have soooo many more hours clocked into this game than Steam is showing. I am mostly playing in offline mode and I also played a lot of it before it even hit Steam. 
This game is a masterpiece. Simply put. 
It was my first Total War game. It made it one of ,if not my favourite gaming franchise.
Being released in 2002 it holds up really damn well to today's standards.

The premise is simple. Total War. Military and diplomatic simulator. But its mostly war. Be ready to destroy every other faction on the map to please your inner warlord.
The game is picked up pretty easily. The mechanics are nothing to be scared off. Nothing on a Paradox Interactive level of complexity. However, it is quite the challenge to master it and beating a campaign on Expert requires some solid learning and skill. The gameplay is rewarding. In terms of AI and difficulty I dare say it surpasses most of its successors. And it's not just the more organized region system to be thanked for this. The Battle AI handles itself and the Campaign AI knows when to attack or when to abandon a province.

Factions play differently from eachother, factors like starting position, religion and culture mean a lot. There are 3 starting dates you can choose from which change the gameplay significantly and the Viking Invasion expansion is also an entire monster on its own. You can fish for mods on the internet and trust me, they are worth it. 
The diplomacy system has less features than any of the newer TW games. You are basically restricted to bribing, allying and organizing royal marriages. Not having diplomats and princesses actually affects your gameplay. Now, despite the fewer options diplomacy is more reliable, allies are not complete backstabbing assholes, alliances are tied really quickly, AI factions usually make the right decision in choosing between two allies and not a single game will be the same. Individual nits are assigned their own named leaders which are given their own stats like loyalty, piety and others. Micromanagement and immersion are perfectly implemented. The construction system encourages variation in city building and region management. (Features that have been completely bareboned in the newest installments)
The army system is in my opinion one of the best TW has ever offered. I am especially impressed by the mercenary system, units which you can only recruit by building an Inn. And it's exciting getting travelling vikings or Italian Militia fighting for you, Spain, in Northern Africa. The autoresolve system for battles works perfectly. You have to take in account not just numbers but bonuses, counters and especially the rank of your general. And you will need the autoresolve system because here is my first con.
Battles are outdated. You can fight them, you can win them, you can enjoy them. But coming from newer games the interface is clunky, you can only zoom in so far and the graphics are barely pleasant. 
Back to graphics, the campaign user interface, the menu, the portraits and the overall artistic style of the game is timeless. There's something enthralling about it and it really captures the medieval atmosphere, especially combined with the glorious soundtrack. Yes, the soundtrack is divine, immersing, flawlessly medieval.

Overall, the gameplay is top notch and you will find yourself pressing for the next turn more than you'd like to. If you can enjoy the sprite battles even better. Medieval 1 is a perfect example of a game that can resist time by simply having solid features.

9/10, the price is totally worth it.

Pros:
Gameplay
Artstyle
SOUNDTRACK
Difficulty
Replayability
Educational :)

Cons:
Outdated battle graphics

author: {'steamid': '76561198007660248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 8579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2507, 'last_played': 1686716574}
review:
I can understand the mixed reviews given that this game is 14 years old. But me personally, I'll always tresure this game. It did more then turn me on to the Total War series. It turned the spark I have always had for history into a roaring flame, that never deminished. This game really captures the primitive nature of the medieval world. 

Also, its one of the few games that I have been playing for years. Most games are cool when you first play them, but this game, I get just as much fun out of playing every single time as I did when I first plugged it in. Probably due to the fact that no two games are ever the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082050583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1476699369}
review: Pretty much the game that consumed my early childhood. My friend gave it to me for some jelly beans; true story. Besides the game crashing randomly I find myself having fun revisiting it. This game is a great example to aspiring game developers as it shows graphics aren't the source of our entertainment but rather actual gameplay mechanics, sounds and other various things that help with immersion. This game feels like it was created by someone who wanted to make a game, not someone wanting to make a game for money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000235949', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1654670347}
review:
first for all those people that have problems, i've been playing full games with no crashing. i set the game to windows compat. mode XP service pack 3. i change the rez of the game map and battle map to fit my desktop rez. i run the program as an administrator and you can't launch the game from steam. you have to go to the Medieval_TW.exe in your steam files and launch it. also quick saves can corrupt save game files so only (Esc button) saves work. also the battles may also cause crashing. try not to play the battle just auto resolve. i run windows 7 and don't have any problems after two games.

-The story
this is the first total war i have ever played. this game brings me back to when i had a pci (not pci E) graphics card slot and couldn't play this game on my dell (agp card slots were the fastest at that time). i would read the manual in math class looking at the cool units and campaign map. how the 3D'ish battles worked and looked. then i would go home and look at the intro to the game just for it to crash as i hit start a new game. i wanted to play it so bad and after begging my mother at comp USA to get me a better card my dell could finally play the game (i was 14 i think). my first time going into the campaign map was just as the manual had explained. a chess like setup with 3D'ish battles and with whole armys I MADE. never before had a game stood out to me as being a real commanding game. i would say if you can stand the graphics then get this game to feel like a true military commander and statesman.

author: {'steamid': '76561198206888261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1701709739}
review: As much as I would love to recommend this game, I cannot. It gave me hours upon hours of enjoyment, being the game that really got me hooked on games, and I truly wished to be able to enjoy the steam version. Alas, it was not to be. The steam version is completely unstable, I do recall the game crashing with a certain consistency, but they were often due to me playing for too long. The crashes now  are often when you end a turn, start a battle, or just try to launch the game. I am greatly disappointed with the state of this game that I love so dearly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198203087103', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1601940503}
review:
SO I was playing on the viking expansion for this game and it has a very specific problem. When I select Cyril (adjacent to Reget), it needs me to press esc to progress any further and then of anyone invades the province, the game crashes, very weird.

But enough of minor glitches that need fixing, on to the game. It's Medieval: Total War, probably the best medieval strategy game that has ever lived (until medieval 2 came around anyways). WHAT DO YOU MEAN I NEED TO EXPLAIN? I don't need to explain anything, just play the game because it was my childhood and it still holds up today, it might even be a timeless classic in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062469785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1548385176}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000525316', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1598042719}
review:
Playing on Windows 7; no crashes so far. It's a shame to see so many people reporting issues. A classic game like this really cries out for a proper GOG-style optimization for modern systems.

Medieval and Shogun are great examples of art from adversity. Wonderful atmosphere and immersion thanks to memorable music, crunchy sound design, beautiful campaign maps, and a plethora of creative design decisions. These games still have the most generous and interesting historical battles in the entire series, as well as the most competent AI, both on the campaign map and in battles. Even though the battle maps and pixelated units are a far cry from where the series is today, the excellence in design of the first two TW games still shines through and makes them worth playing today.

The cons: Medieval has a disappointingly passive campaign AI. It loves to make alliances and rarely declares war. Also, while the building system offers much more flexibility than recent games in the series, becomes seriously tedious to manage once you have a large empire. 

Recommended for fans of the series who want to explore its early heritage, and for those (like me) who loved this game back in the day and want to relive those memories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024806132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1574881579}

author: {'steamid': '76561197979686280', 'num_games_owned': 334, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 7928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6362, 'last_played': 1694555409}
review: Best TW game ever made by CA. Risk style campaign map works well with the AI and holds up to this day and the game has a good amount of interesting mechanics not present in any newer Total War game. Knights can dismount before battle, every unit has a named officer with stats and traits, allies can be betrayed in the middle of battle, and you can pick which side of a rebellion you want to fight for.  It's criminal that CA hasn't released a patch for original owners of MTW to play the game on newer systems though. Also worth mentioning I haven't had any crashing issues replaying the game with the new patch on Windows 7. If you have crash issues, set campaign map resolution to 1280x720 and your desktop resolution to 1280x720 as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054264492', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1519825954}
review:
Crap...absolute crap!  I loved this game back in the day when it was new. I would spend days, sometimes weeks on campagins.  The battle stratagy, economis, everything about this game is amazing.  BUT, like several other people ive seen in the reviews, the game crashes waaaay to much.  Played for 30min, crashed 3 times. tried again awhile later played another 30min, crashed 5 times.  nothing in particular when it crashes its 100% random.  Im using Win7 and a lot of people having this issue seemed to be using 10 so thought i would be ok but NOPE.  I do NOT suggest buying this game.  I wanted to play something fun from the older days of gaming but i would have rather paid twice what i did for this for a hardcopy that actually works.  Can't even get a refund now.  friggin rip off, 

***DO NOT BUY IT***


***EDIT**
Found a thread saying to adjust resolution to fit your screen. This appears to have worked. Made it through a campagin without it crashing but still dont know. If you would be upset to loose the money i wouldent buy it just to be safe.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976259902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 843, 'last_played': 1589803816}
review:
Okay, fair enough it crashes every once in a while, as you'll have read on a number of other reviews.

Despite this the game is as good as it ever was. Total War at it's most simple. Save it regularly and the occasional crash will barely bother you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034615512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 448, 'last_played': 1690565660}
review:
Bought this one recently on steam. So many memories... This game is a great addition in the Total War series and i actually prefer this type (tabletop - board game like) of gameplay on the campaign map.  The A.I. is exceptional and can be very challenging while the game is very balanced. I also love the fact that they give you 3 different periods to choose from when you begin a campaign.
I was afraid to buy it at first cuz of all the posts about game crashes etc but it works fine on my PC.

review:
MTW:G not working on Win-10 (Pro 64bits) - Build 10586 ..


Okay, I would definitely rate this game 10/10 IF it worked properly.


I've literally tried every trick in the book, or every "solution" I found online,
and NOTHING seems to work!!


First I did a clean install of Win10. I updated ALL my drivers. I installed Steam. Then I installed STW:WE, Shogun TW 2, and then I installed MTW:G.
Both Shogun 1 AND 2 work just fine after some tweaking. (Compat-mode Win7 etc.)


But MTW:G?? Nothing! I get the intro, then black screen, no sound, nothing..


So I've tried using every single compatibility available, with every setting possible (16-bit colors, 8-bit colors, starting as admin with desktop-shortcut, etc.) and changing my screen resolution to every option available. And that's A LOT! (800*600, 1024*786, etc.)


Nothing seems to work. I've even tried doing this whole process again and ONLY installing Mediaval TW Gold..


Anyone else has this problem or has any tips for me? I'm usually pretty good with stuff like this, being a gamer for over 21 years, but this has kept me baffled for ages now -____-

DO NOT BUY IF YOU HAVE THE LATEST VERSION OF WIN10!!


BTW:
The first one to come with a solution that works gets a game worth around 5€. (In Steam's summersale that's a lot :D )

author: {'steamid': '76561198018962623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1723, 'last_played': 1589432719}
review:
I played this game initially before Med2, a game which I was terribly addicted to. With the death of my desktop, I installed this beauty for a measly $2.50 (thanks, Steam!). To say the least, it has surpassed it's value ten fold. "Is it really as good as a $25 game?", you ask. The answer to that question varies from  "THOSE PIGS BROKE OUR ALLIANCE!" to "Watch them flee. I love watching the enemies flee." and even "I... I lost!?". Losing never felt so good. It leaves you changing your view from "How could my idiots let me down?" to "How could I let down my brave soldiers?".. that's a lesson you can carry to victory in ANY game.
-
  The gameplay. If you don't know this game, let's just say the obvious: It's responsible for funding a team who would create the most celebrated and brutal historical war simulation games, ever. Yes there are a few NOT made by the Total War team that are amazing, this is true. However, would those games have been as good if the Total War franchise didn't exist? I think not. The Corvette didn't become the 650 horsepower sternum-crushing monster it is becase there are no other cars in the world to compete with, right?
  Play as several factions, each one like a historical counterpart. The Total War team skirts historical inaccuracies by saying "Before countries, there were only kingdoms", or something to the tune of that. It doesn't matter that it's not 100% historically delicious, this is a strategy game first, history channel lesson second.
 Raise armies, make alliances, fight pitched battles. Switch between campaign map mode, which resembles what a grisly old emperor might look over to play war games with his neighbors; and battle mode. Battle mode is where the soldiers you chose to fight get to live up to their duties. This is where the middle ages greatest leaders made their names. Where they won their spurs. Thousands of soldiers fighting to the death, following your careful command. Battles lines are formed, archers are readied, cavalary are signalled and the fates of a kingdom, of and empire are decided!
  
-
  One of the biggest problems with retro gaming is compatibility and dealing with the graphics. This game hurdles those problems (for me).
   I have a laptop with no-name hardware, backed by some watered down Radeon card from years past. Retro PC gaming isn't as simple as consoles, however my hardware didn't hesitate to show it understood how to process MTW1, although I may have installed a wrapper. (If you don't know what a wrapper is, look it up. Glide wrapper, D3d, Direct Draw for example, make your graphics card able to read the outdated or defunct engines of years past. I installed one for D2 which may have made a difference)
  The graphics are spot on, the menus crisp and animation as claymation as the day it came out. That sounds like a bad thing to some, but remember that the early 2000's is a hard pill to swallow when you're dealing with small scale 3D modelling. It's far better with the enhanced 2D style, especially for gamers who remember just how awesome MYTH 1 and 2 were, compared to 3. Imagine Diablo 2 with horrible nearly PS1 era 3D models. Wicked bad. The resolutions, I suspect, were updated. Running this game on higher resolution on a bigger monitor only makes this game better. All of the usual resolutions are available, max at 1920x1080
-
  The iffy. The iffy is that I am running this game, like all my retro games, on WIN7. I run WIN7 because I can't run the new games due to the watered down GPU I have, and if I can't run new games.. or old games..than why PC? I have read that there are a lot of problems with WIN10 and retro games. In the beginning there were a lot of problems with retro software on every version of Windows, so this is nothing new. 
-
  I will be getting a WIN10 tablet in two weeks. Real WIN10, not "RT". "RT" is a mall cop to a Fox Moulder. Then, I will play this game on that tablet, no matter how much it fails to make sense. Mark my words, Sancho, that gold is mine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027258976', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1301, 'last_played': 1686341946}
review: I cannot recommend this game highly enough. It is hands down the best title in the Total War series. It has all the grand strategic depth you want with none of the unnecessary layers of complexity later titles offer. The tactical battles will feel a little dated, particularly if you've played a new TW game; however they still offer the chance to exercise your inner general. I don't have Windows 10 so I can't comment on those compatibility issues; however it has run fine on my 8.1 machine since purchase. I have had one crash when going to game menu once. Not sure why and hasn't happened again in many hours of playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070679977', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1957, 'last_played': 1618091070}
review:
This is one of the 'classics' and the game that got me into the Total War franchise and definitely holds up as a game despite being a zillion years old.

However, and I implore you to keep this in mind, this game crashes a lot, it is not something new, and seems like something unadressed and will likely will only get worse with the inexirable advance of software and hardware. I strongly recommend buying this game only when it is on sale and worth a few pence for you might feel robbed otherwise.

Coming to the game itself, this is possibly one of the best games when it was made and certainly a landmark in the Total War franchise. It is still a strong game and different enough from other Total Wars to be worth playing because it combines some of that realm and vassal management, giving it that extra realism that was lacking in later games and the battles are in awesome 2-D, graphics aside it all holds up very well.
So I highly recommend this game but also caution you about the minefield of crashes that can occur when playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134008142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1465550185}
review: In my opinion, this is one of the worst games in Total War saga: very low quality graphic (the landscape and soldiers' equipment details are not well defined) and you have a strange feeling while playing, because "the point of view" is absent and so it seems that you cannot participate in the struggle. Total war saga is excellent since rome total war, but medieval total war, that is a bit elder, seems to be a first experiment, an absolutely not well done experiment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073938399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 955, 'last_played': 1466237032}

author: {'steamid': '76561198138207634', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1379, 'last_played': 1709183832}
review:
Medieval 1 is a fantastic game.  This was the second total war game ever released, and when you play it it becomes obvious how it started such a vast franchise.

The gameplay is very similar to the total war games that came after it.  It has inferior graphics and it's UI is slightly less intuitive.  This is balanced by the fact that the campaign screen is much more interesting with more strategic depth.  Everything sticks to a great, weird, "dark-medieval" theme, from the character portraits to the art etc.  None of the other total war games maintain this kind of unique theme.

My one complaint is that it frequently crashed on the default resolution setting, and I had to play around with the resolution settings to get it to run without crashes.  Not sure why.  If you're experiencing crashing try changing resolution.

review: Если честно, господа, то я её случайно купил:D Купил... и удивился, что это самая крутая стратегия тех времен, и даже несмотря на графику 1998 года(игра вышла позже, но не суть) и спрайтовые войска она отлично смотрится. Жаль, что так мало людей в 2016 году способны её оценить по достоинству, так как движок стар как останки мамонта и игру потянет даже банкомат. Знаю, что прародителем всей серии является Shogun: Total War, но Medieval можно считать улучшеной версией, так как увеличилось кол-во построек и прочих плюшек(династические браки, осадные свистоперделки и сам Папа Римский!). Играть в нее посоветую только олдфагам и старожилам серии.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039580049', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 400, 'playtime_forever': 51900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3941, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1711505763}
review: Guide the destiny of your dominion and armies through 400 years of medieval history, featuring a great balance of addictive Risk-style empire building (presented on a tabletop with pawns as your units) and great combat realism and strategic depth. Medieval: Total War improves on its superb predecessor Shogun in almost every way. Just remember this is an old game which has its flaws, but at the time it was amazing. Get this game, if you're a fan of the Total War series and enjoy the nostalgic feel when playing a classic magnificent game. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=680829711 http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=680805540

author: {'steamid': '76561198040859614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1708417646}
review:
Despite the No, I still recommend you to try... as long that it doesnt crash.

PROS:
MTW XL (Thats alot of factions to choose.)
Lots of Units! (Or maybe too much)
Debug Mode  (Fun switching to Italians to make them inbreds, then to England to spy, then other teams to destroy border forts...)

CONS:
Pirated versions is better. (THX PIRATES) 
Crashes often. (I have to switch to 1280x720 in order to 
Oh boy, those goddamn Inquistors, more of a problem in here than MTW2.
Can't run on steam with Debug Mode :(
Cival wars
They went WAAAAY overboard with the Border forts. 
Siege battles (High casualties)

Rating: 4/10 - 
First off... The MTW XL Mod is required in order to play this game without being bored. MTW2 is recommended instead. 
Second, This game crashes alot. The resolution 1280x720 was tested without any crashes (Hopefully). 
Third... this game gets bored in 10 minutes or so due to "What should I build/train", and likely the "omg, wtf is with my men?!?"
Fourth... For players who played Shogun 1... It's not like Shogun. Sieges WILL destroy your army, oh, have a 1000 men army? You're going to have 600+ Casualty if you win. Assassins and Spies are more useful as Policemen, which I meant killing any pesky Inquistors taking a dump on your generals. 
Fifth... For any players who played MTW2, you would really want to press the emergency escape button and stay in MTW2. Traits in this game run wild, since most of the generals really are perverted and want boys. (IMNOTKIDDING)
And lastly... The pirated versions works better. No crashing, but with those flickers. Seriously. 

Why did I buy this game? MTW XL. I recommend playing Medieval 2 Total War.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970425590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1554, 'last_played': 1463241409}
review:
QUICK NOTE ON PERFORMANCE: I have Windows 7, intel CPU and an AMD graphics card, which seems to be the best PC spec for the game. I haven't experienced a single bug or crash with this setup.

Medieval 1 is, for me, the best of the Total War series. The risk-style campaign map offers the best strategising compared to the 3D campaign maps in the follow up games, which the AI never managed to properly make use of.

Here, it is a cutthroat, tense battle of wills at each end of game turn as you wait to see if a faction sends their giant army stacks into your territories. Many tough decisions have to be made when it comes to balancing your forces. It's perfectly streamlined and never gets bogged down.

The battles, too, are superior to the follow up games. Units take their time climbing hills, slowly whittling eachother down in combat, allowing proper tactical changes during battles. You truly feel like a general directing a battle, unlike the 5 minute mass brawls of Rome/Med2 which ended up resembling some Benny Hill inspired, fast forwarded mess. 

The game engenders that feeling of intrigue and epic storytelling more than any other TW.

So, if you feel your PC setup can get it running properly, I heartily recommend picking this up. It's arguably one of the very best PC games of all time and still holds up remarkably well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024504408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 29047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5851, 'last_played': 1705272565}
review:
Sometimes superficially compared to Risk because of its use of "Regions" and armies that occupy them in the strategic aspect of the game; Medieval: Total War is, like Shogun: Total War before it, a very unique sort of game. You play as a sort of "animating spirit" of a nation and guide it on to glory, honor, and conquest across Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East. Gameplay involves two main aspects: the Campaign Map and the Battles that are fought to resolve military actions on campaign.

In the Campaign Map you have armies, agents, regions, and the castles in regions. 

You make economic choices such as the risk management of the unrest that higher taxation causes, which buildings are most beneficial to a region's income and whether or not you can protect the investment in that region, and whether you want to leave your titles of land to the men who are most loyal, leave them to the men who can manage the agriculture the best, or wait for the uncommon man who fits both criteria and will be a true asset to your rich interior regions. 

But along with economy and land come those who covet it, and war that claims lives and land is part of the game. Your military infrastructure permits your recruitment of navies and armies, and your military strategy regarding the movement of those armies is just as important as if not more so than your military tactics regarding battles. To defeat an army of your strength in a clean victory that pushes him back to another region is one thing. To completely outmaneuver him, annihilate the majority of his forces in detail, and leave his pathetic remnants holed up in their keeps in lands they no longer control is another, and the difference is when and where you fight your battles.

In the real time battles things are much more straightforward: you have your men, they have theirs, and not everyone who enters the battlefield is leaving it.

Analyze your troop composition, analyze their composition, analyze the terrain near yourself, analyze the terrain near them. Do you wait for them to make the first move, and act upon what they are committing to? Do you take the initiative yourself, hoping for (or in the best case, assured of) getting an advantage that will take you a step closer to victory?

Your units have their own varied personalities. Sometimes they fight you. The impetuous feudal knights who charge home into the enemy may plainly refuse to disengage on your order or, in the worst case, attempt to and fail as they are cut down because only a portion of them followed the order. Highlanders ready and willing to slaughter are themselves not so stiff of character and from just a volley or two or archer fire may break and flee as their pathetic discipline proves to be their downfall. After you lose this battle, those very same highlanders may prove themselves to be your greatest asset as the enemy pursues you and your men charge downhill out of the woods, slaughtering and turning the enemy mass in the face of such raw force.

To conclude, Medieval: Total War is certainly a unique game and a satisfying one if you appreciate a test of both your strategic and tactical skills. I recommend if you play this game to avoid savescumming every turn to outmaneuver enemy armies. It takes a lot of the challenge out of the strategy when you know exactly what your opponent is going to do next when he cannot do the same with you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132994764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 33875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4803, 'last_played': 1701320788}
review:
All the negative reviews seem to be because the game crashes and is unplayable. Here's a fix that worked for me and everyone else I know of who tried it.

Find out what screen resolution your computer is set at. 
When the game starts go to options, graphics options .
Set the game screen resolution to what your computer screen resoltion is.

That's all there is to it. Saved games work in the new resolution.
Now on to a very quick review since I'm mostly just posting a fix for the crashes
 
Edit: deidaraakatski was kind enough to let me know that checking the disable tool tips from the pull out menu on the campain map also helps. Before I did that I was getting some game crashes before larger battles. I've had no crashes since I changed that option.

I am not a huge RTS fan and find the total war games from Medieval 2 on to be more mob rules then real strategy. The battles of Medieval are slow compaired to newer titles. You start with oponents very far from one another allowing you to adjust and readjust formations before the armies clash. This won't be everyones idea of fun, but I enjoy the challange of trying to win the tough battles or even just keep my sides casulties down.
The main negative for me is the naval battles that seem to be random chance. Bigger navy, better odds. Otherwise a game that I greatly enjoy. The small details like the names of the ruling houses and the generals, and the historical events that happen during play give the game a very nice feel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099067935', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1674453402}
review: So look, this can be a fantastic game.  It's all the best things that a Total War game can be - immense continent-spanning campaigns, intrigue, evolving tech tree, smart AI (much more so than later Total Wars), a lovely atmospheric soundtrack, and a wide range of possible strategies and tactics.  Yes, the graphics now look really poor compared to later efforts, although the campaign map still looks very nice. But, and it is a big but, me and many others find the game unplayably unstable, with frequent crashes as the campaing goes on.  For me at least, the patches have not had any improvement, and sadly I am not alone in that.  There is an awesome game hiding in here, and its worth $10 of your money to give it a go.  Just dont be surpised if the technical glitches make it a frsutrating, maybe unplayable, experience for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981638563', 'num_games_owned': 4007, 'num_reviews': 517, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1457477925}
review:
[b]MEDIEVAL: Total War[/b] is a sequel to [b]SHŌGUN: Total War[/b] game that was made by [b]The Creative Assembly[/b] and released in [b]2000[/b]. Even though the project began as a typical [b]WarCraft[/b]-like [b]RTS[/b], it grew into pretty detailed and realistic strategy game, based on real history and with some real historical battles in it. [b]MEDIEVAL: Total War[/b] isn’t trying to invent the wheel again. At the first look it may even look like a simple reskin of [b]SHŌGUN[/b]. And technically, it’s true. If you’ll look into the game files, you’ll notice that units still have stats like “samurai”, and, of course, the game structure remains the same. Which means that we have heavily customizable [b]Civilization[/b]-like campaign, a set of so-called [b]Historical Campaigns[/b], that offer some puzzle-like tactical on-field experience, and also some [b]Historical Battles[/b] that try to recreate some famous battles from the past. In other words, it looks like the same exact thing, just in medieval setting. But the more you’ll play, the more you’ll see that [b]MEDIEVAL[/b] is actually a pretty big improvement.

First of all, [b]The Creative Assembly[/b] polished the interface in the main campaign. Useless adviser disappeared, but now you’ll feel much more comfortable and it’ll be much harder to miss the important things. Like now when you’ll click on the city you’ll see what units and buildings are currently in production there. One click will tell you everything and if you’ll need some extra info about the buildings and units, all you’ll need to do is to right click on the corresponding icon. The game really became more comfortable.

Moreover, it became much bigger. There are more playable sides, the world is bigger (for obvious reasons), there are more units, more buildings, etc. But the most interesting thing about the main campaign here is that generals are now really, I mean [i]really[/i] important. Ninja in [b]SHŌGUN[/b] were pretty cool, but only in [b]MEDIEVAL[/b] you’ll feel the real tragedy when your general will die, killed by assassin. I can’t say that the game got proper [b]RPG[/b] elements, but generals now are really complicated and if you want to win, you’ll need to pay close attention to their personalities. There’s also a new interesting factor - religion. Since the game takes place in medieval [b]Europe[/b], we have [b]Orthodox Christianity[/b], [b]Catholicism[/b] and [b]Islam[/b]. And those aren’t just words, you’ll really use them in the game. Say hello to [b]Europa Universalis[/b] series, since you’ll use the religion to keep your citizens loyal, for example. It's not the only use for religion, of course. You can actually use the religion as a part of the political war against your enemies.

That’s right, now you can put [i]much[/i] more pressure on your enemies without fighting them with swords than you were able in [b]SHŌGUN[/b]. Even religion isn’t the only way, even though using your religious figures to sabotage the moral on enemy territory is extremely fun. Emissaries became much more useful now and thanks to them you’ll be able to create a big web of spies. Marriages, bribes, dirty diplomacy, all that adds a lot to the experience and makes the main campaign in [b]MEDIEVAL: Total War[/b] feels like a proper and pretty deep [b]Grand Strategy[/b]. [b]SHŌGUN[/b] tried to combine different genres, but at the same time it tried not to go too deep into them. [b]MEDIEVAL[/b] is trying to keep what [b]SHŌGUN[/b] achieved, but at the same time to make all that as deep as possible.

Even tactical battles became much deeper. Landscapes are much more complicated now, there are now some extra things to worry about (like some [b]Historical Campaigns[/b] include time limit, while the others will ask you to hold certain position, etc), but the most delicious thing is, of course, the sieges. Technically, there were castles in [b]SHŌGUN[/b] too, but only in [b]MEDIEVAL[/b] you’ll have tools like ballistas that will help you to smash through the castle walls. Smashing the walls, getting to the enemy troops inside, taking the castle and holding it… The whole thing feels extremely real now.

So, in the end, even though [b]MEDIEVAL: Total War[/b] may look like the same exact thing all over again, give it a chance and play a little. Then you’ll understand how many things are improved here. Yes, [b]MEDIEVAL: Total War[/b] didn’t make a new revolution, but there was just no need for it. What we needed here is an evolution and that’s exactly what [b]MEDIEVAL: Total War[/b] does best. It’s a heavily polished and evolved version of [b]SHŌGUN: Total War[/b]. Bigger, better, more complicated, tricky and interesting. If you liked [b]SHŌGUN[/b], you’ll [i]love[/i] [b]MEDIEVAL[/b].

review:
medieval: total war ist vom inhalt bis heute ein gutes rundenbasiertes strategiespiel mit verschiedenen einheiten je nach zivilisation und auch region, der möglichkeit eines kontinuirlichen ausbau der gebäude innerhalb der regionen was verbesserungen mit sich bringt und das immerwieder auch historische ereignisse wie der mongolensturm oder die pest im spiel vorkommen.  inhaltlich lässt sich bis heute lediglich bemängeln lässt das ein erstmal begonnener krieg sich nur militärisch beenden lässt
Das tatsächliche problem ist nich der inhalt sondern das dieses spiel bei allen versuchen es zu spielen bei mir zielgenau abgestürzt ist sobald man den grundsätzlichen aufbau seiner fraktion beendet hat und mit dem krieg führen beginnt und damit zwangsläufig auf den spaßigsten teil des spiels verzichten muss.
wer die cd noch haben sollte empfehle ich die zu benutzen oder wenigstens von der steamversion abstand zu nehmen es sei den man hat große lust sich unnötig und dazu noch für geld zu ärgern
