author: {'steamid': '76561198007486006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1527273590}
review:
A true classic, a must have. Yes, it is old. Yes, the graphics of the RTS part is awful. But yes, it still is a great game. The infinite possibilities of moulding history to your liking, the unique bond you develop with your generals and their equally unique stories and traits, the purely Medieval feeling of your chess-like TBS map... For me, it is also the memories: Medieval was my first Total War, my first strategy game on PC, and the beginning of an age. I can't recount all the hours spent in front of it when I was a child with a weird taste in games, who enjoyed conquering the world a lot more than making weird animals jump over wooden crates (yes, mr. Bandicoot, I'm talking to you).

PS Don't be confused by my scarce gameplay time - I used to own a retail version and I totally played the heck out of it for years and years!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053779937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1462, 'last_played': 1676966210}
review:
Excelente juego, no he tenido ningún problema de crasheo y nada, supongo que debes tomar en cuenta la lap o pc que tienes al momento de comprar este juego (Y desconozco que hay que tener para que no suceda) lo he jugado mucho en el pasado, lo juego ahora en el presente y lo seguire jugando en el futuro.

Para los que no sepan de que va la cosa, es sencillo, controlara una nación, lo que quiere significar: Ejercito, Tierras, Reinado, Economia,  etc. Los por menores de cada habito le dan vida a este juego ¿A que me refiero con por menores? Pues creo que en sí, a todo el juego jajaja.

Veran, los ejercitos, divididos en pelotones y estos a su vez con un lider que es quien representa la cara del ejercito (aunque el juego te hace ver que solo es "el" a quien representan las caracteristicas), tienen ciertos vicios (o defectos más bien) y virtudes que los premian y hacen diferentes entre si, algunos ganables otros heredables simplemente o incluso simplemente adquiribles por el azar de la vida, además de cosas a tomar en cuenta con mucho peso, lealtad, terror (aqui el miedo puede hacer que una batalla sea ganada sin librarla), astucia (que no sirve en el campo de batalla, ya veran para que si), fe (aunque no se llama así, la religión también tiene su papel aqui) y finalmente mando, que da una  enorme ventaja en batalla, siendo este el más importante dentro del campo de batalla al bonificar a tus unidades (Como cuando el Cid Campeador ha ganado la guerra estando ya muerto, la moral que le brinda a la gente un general bueno).

Por otra parte, estan los territorios, cada uno es un estado que debes manejar individualmente: Construir edificios, ver cuanto cobrar anualmente, si tu gente esta feliz o no (que puede conllevar una rebelion del pueblo), lo cual a veces significa tenerlas a punta de espadas a ralla (a quien le gusta ser conquistado despues de todo?) y los terrenos seran beneficiados por quien este a cargo (donde entra la astucia de los personajes, su pericia para los negocios).

Aunque es un juego basado en turnos (que son representados como años) puedes jugarlo de dos maneras: La primera es como un juego de tablero autoresolutivo, lo que quiere decir que trabaja con numeros y automaticos: Se decide la batalla mediante las estadisticas de los bandos; o puedes bien librar tus propias batallas y comandar tu ejercito totalmente en primera mano, usualmente esto es mejor si quieres ganar una batalla por tu cuenta especialmente dificil que normalmente perderías pues las estadisticas demostraban lo contrario ¿A que mola eso?. Finalmente, terminar una partida puede hacerse muy larga y tediosa para algunos pero quienes disfruten del genero lo disfrutaran, inclusive puedes jugarlo de manera rapida haciendo que todo se resuelva en automatico o tomarte tu tiempo para conquistar el mundo.

Un juegaso sin duda que recomiendo comprar para los que no conocen de la franquicia, es la primera joya que encontre cuando apenas salio en sus inicios y hasta hace un par de meses volví a conseguir aqui mismo en steam, claro que lo he comprado en rebaja jajajaja pero bueno, quienes esten dispuestos a probarlo con todo el precio adelante, si no, consideren gastar un poco en este pequeño diamante

author: {'steamid': '76561198144827512', 'num_games_owned': 83, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 4468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3795, 'last_played': 1456686846}
review:
O jogo é muito bom para os amantes da série. E, se tratando de um clássico e sem analisar graficamente, recomendo o jogo.
O único ponto que me decepcionou, foi a fraca inteligência artificial. Mesmo no expert, se você conseguir passar dos primeiros anos (que são os mais desafiadores) a CPU irá fugir de seu exército na maioria das batalhas e não será uma ameaça naquelas em que ela lutar. Pra manter a diversão, você não deve utilizar força máxima em todas as batalhas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070580539', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 717, 'last_played': 1457891578}
review:
NOTE: I'm playing this without any problems on windows 10, but I've seen many support requests from people running my OS. Bottom line, this game may or may not work on your windows 10 system. 

That being said, I think this game is a classic. It far simpler than some of the newer Total War titles, but it makes it easier for RTS newbies such as myself.  

The elephant in the room of course, is the ancient graphics. All troopers in the 3D battlefield are 2D sprites, but always changing/angleing to the camera to give the illusion it's all 3D. It doesn't do a bad job of pulling it off, but it isn't nearly as good as, say Total War Medieval 2. (I suppose that goes without saying :D)

As far as the campaign goes, the map is not a 3D world, but more of a traditional paper looking map. It's more colorful than the first TW game, Shogun, and it's personally my favorite style. 

The goal of the campaign is to start in a country, build your armies, and then INVADE! Invade other countries, but beware: as your army grows, and you have more to manage, some generals may rebel. (When my generals are about to rebel, I like to send them by themselves to figth a HUGE enemy army. It gets the job done well. )

Overall, I think this is a fun game, and well worth the few dollars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029462593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1454691937}
review:
This is a brilliant game, one of my favourites. However, if you are using anything newer than Windows XP then just forget it. Direct Sound was deprecated in Vista and so far as I can gather it is specifically the cause of the relentless crashes which have been reported over and over and over again on this review listing. It is UNPLAYABLE.

This game needs to be either patched, drastically reduced in price or else removed entirely.

NOTE: The price has suddenly been reduced from £6.99 to £1.74, so it is at least more feasible to take the risk in hoping it will work. I would not at all be surprised if it has been reduced because of the constistent reports of crashes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046575783', 'num_games_owned': 375, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1051, 'last_played': 1662784441}
review:
TL;DR

Yes.

Okay, the long version.

Yeeeessss.

Now with details:

+ Still fun after all these years. How many? 15. Crazy, right?
+ Sure the graphics are pixelated and old, but it doesn't strain the eyes that much.
+ Vices and Vurtues are actually important (unlike in other TW games).
+ Stomping around the campaign map is like hardcore chess.
+Autosaves. I'm listing it because 1) crashes (see below), and 2) old games didn't always have these.

- Random crashes, although when I reload they sometimes happen again when performing the same action. Dunno why.
- Map can get cluttered, especially in small provinces.
- Can sometimes be difficult to figure out what's affecting a province's faith/happiness/income in which ways.
- Occasionally annoying ocean movement (no indicator if you can/can't ferry troops across the sea).

If you never played TW, it may be a bit obtuse at times but its honestly not that hard.
If you've played the newer ones, this sure as hell ain't like those. Prepare to relearn everything.

8/10, would let my pedophillic atheistic Spanish king get embroiled in adultery and kill the Pope again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107222423', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 14719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1498, 'last_played': 1610569467}
review:
This is one of my favorite total war games. I have been plying the series since the first one: Shogun Total War.
Those two games made a few things better then more recent total war games and that is why I still love playing them.
First one the strategic map played differently. It was not as visually appealing and it did not try to look like the actual terain you are conquerring. It looked just like a map but the way it worked allowed for much more depth in the strategic maneuvers that newer titles of the series do not allow.
Instead of marching your armies around the map similar to Heroes of Maith and Magic, you moved your amrmies only from one province to adjacent provine. If at the end of the turn there are two rival armies in the same provine, they fight an open battle. Sounds very simple and without much depth, but that approach allowes for one very inportant difference: all factions turns are played at the same time. In the Heroes style of starategic movement, when you march your army and meet another army, you can attack them and they can not escape because it is your turn. They can withdraw just once a couple of tiles away, but if you still have movement points and attack them again they are trapped. If they are in a city and you besiege them, they have to either sally our and defeat you, or just stay and stavre to death. They can not run away. You just have to create a strong army and march arount conquering everithing that stands before you. Any army you can reach withihn your turn you can destroy.
In Medival TW I and Shogun TW I, when you are attacked you have a choise: you can fight the battle, you can reatreat to your stronghold(if there is any in this province) or you can abbandon the province. This gives much more stratgic options. When you are attacked you can give ground to the enemy and regroup your troops. The further the enemy goes in your teritory the more troops they have to leave behind as a garrison to maintain order in the  conquerred terrytory and your retreating troops combine with more troops from other provinces, so your army is getting stronger and the invader is getting weakr. You can choose where to fight. You can avoud his main army and just attak weak provinces and so on. This also gives many options to the attacker. You may attack with overwhelming force some central provinces cutting the enemy empire to peaces, isolating his armies, and then attacking each pocket with concentrated strength. You can attack multiple provinces at once cutting the reatreat of any troops so they got captured at the border without a fight and outmaneuvre your opponent and destroy him without battle.
Sure this does not allow for other cool strategies like having more strategic mobility then your enemies by creating an entire army of cavlary like the steppe nomads. You can't do that because all armies move just one province at a time but the strategic depth is definitely supperior to the Heroes style total war games.

Another thing that I like abouth the first two total war games are the battles. At first glance they look very bad compared to more recent TW games. If however you don't look at the details but instead look at the action and the dynamics of the battle, they look and work much more like a real battle. The battle is much more chaotic. The terrain have much greater effect. The individual soldiers go back and forth, attacking, defending, trying to outmaneuvre each other, they take or give ground, they fight for their lives even when routing. The pace and movement speed of the units is very well made so the battle is not just one big click fest but it requires sound maneuvres and good judgment of timing.

I reccomend this game to every real strategy and war gamer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098013678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 9288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1001, 'last_played': 1647111376}
review:
EDIT: I originally gave this game a negative rating because of frequent crashes.  There is not one universal solution to this problem -- I tried plenty of solutions that solved other peep's problems with the game, but did nothing for me -- but you should be able to find one to fix your particular problem is you try enough of them.  For me, it required a resolution change.

Still my favorite of the Total War games.  

The map in this one (and the original Shogun) functions more like Risk than later games.  Your army controls an entire territory, then can move into an adjacent territories as one unit.  Personally, I preferred this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023417600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1590076222}
review:
เกมเก่าแล้ว กราฟฟิคแบบสามิติยุคแรก ๆ แต่ยังเล่นสนุกอยู่ 

เช่นเคยเป็นแนว Total war คือ เล่นบริหารในโหมดแผนที่สลับกับบัญชาการสงครามบนสนามรบ 

ชอบมาก โดยเฉพาะโหมดแผนที่ที่เราสามารถแต่งตั้งอัศวินให้เป็นขุนนาง เป็นท่าน Duke ท่าน Count เจ้าเมืองต่าง ๆ ได้ด้วย แถมยังมีตำแหน่งเสนาบดี หรือจอมพล อะไรต่าง ๆ ด้วย แต่ละประเทศก็จะมีชื่อเรียกตำแหน่งแตกต่างกันไป ซึ่งไม่มีในภาคใหม่ ๆ เช่น อังกฤษ เดิมหัวหน้าหน่วยชื่อ Sir William ถ้าเราแต่งตั้งเป็นเจ้าเมือง ชื่อก็จะเปลี่ยนเป็น Lord William, Duke of Normandy ถ้าแต่งตั้งตำแหน่งอื่นเข้าไปอีกอย่างเสนาบดีคลัง ก็จะเป็น Lord William, Duke of Normandy, Chancellor of the Exchequer เป็นต้น แต่ละตำแหน่งก็จะเพิ่มค่าความสามารถเข้าไปด้วย

(ระบบตำแหน่งพึ่งกลับมาในภาค Shogun II นิดนึง และ Attila ที่มีการแต่งตั้งเจ้าเมือง และระบบราชการ แต่ยังไงก็ไม่ละเอียดเท่าภาคนี้)

ใครชื่นชอบประวัติศาสตร์ยุคกลางของยุโรปไม่ควรพลาด

author: {'steamid': '76561198066264648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 823, 'last_played': 1507158177}
review:
Many strange things have happened in this game, which is why I like it. Let me list a few events that were odd:

1. Managed to declare a crusade against the papacy. I was excommunicated, but rewarded by el pope when I won.

2. I destroyed france, but one of the princes escaped and rebuilt the French kingdom. In Cyprus.

3. The peasants of scotland revolted, but the garrison in my small hillfort consisting of 100 fellow peasants held out for four years.

4. My young daughter Elizabeth kept trying to get married, but every prince in europe denied her hand. So she was married to a welsh lord I bribed to join our kingdom and forfeit wales. I made him prince of wales, but his son started a civil war for the crown and I let him win. England is now ruled by the welsh.

5. The Kingdom of england grew to encompass nearly all of france, germany, britain, and north italy, but we were still only the english kings.

6. My best king was Stephen II, who took the crown at 15 and ruled for 47 years. He was a fearsome and dreadful ruler, who sacked Paris and Rome in his lifetime, as well as destroying the French, Spanish, and German peoples. He was rich and beloved by all people, and died at the ripe old age of 62. His son, William III, took the crown at 28 and ruled for 4 years before he died of disease. So ended the line of Stephen II.

Overall, my best game has to have been as the english in the high middle ages start. I made King John a great king rather than an evil one, and he managed to bring the french to the point of extinction, and pummeled the excommunicated germans in a bloody crusade for Burgundy, which they had taken from French hands. My only ally at this point is Denmark, which only hold the three scandanavian provinces, but remain staunch supporters of the English monarchy, though we are very close cousins who inbreed constantly to maintain the alliances. 

So yeah a fun game I guess

author: {'steamid': '76561198111862045', 'num_games_owned': 71, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1297, 'last_played': 1640972043}
review:
<--<******Обновление обзора*********>-->

Да это лучшая игра из серии (посматриваю ещё и в сторону новой Total War: Warhammer - заманчиво выглядит для поклонника Вахи ). Игра про самое крутое - средневековье и рыцарей!

Единственный минус - не хватает расширенной дипломатии, но это больше хотелки - более, чем достойная игра для своего и нынешнего времени!

Сперва только в стратегический режим играл *т.к. был нубом в тактических боях. 
После прочтения мануалов от frogbeastegg (добавлены в руководства по игре, и можно найти в моём профиле) захотелось попробовать битву (которые меня привлекали давным-давно в детстве, на пиратке). И это что-то - уж после того, как разберётесь что к чему в игровой механике и с системой "камень-ножницы-бумага", вам станет хотеться этих боёв, и один ход на глобальной карте растянется на пол-часа - час: настолько это увлекательно!!

Спасибо разработчикам за сей шикарный продукт!
И особая благодарность - за стилистику и атмосферу! - Игру не хочется покидать даже после длительного погружения!
Удачи!

author: {'steamid': '76561198064265043', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1599436477}
review:
ATENCIÓN: Mi "NO RECOMENDACIÓN" del juego no se debe a la calidad del juego, que comentaré más abajo, sino a los problemas de compatibilidad. Cuando lo instalo aparece el mensaje "TARJETA GRÁFICA NO SOPORTADA".
Compré este juego (que ya poseía original) con la idea de instalarlo en un viejo portátil. Este portatil, por cierto, es más nuevo que el portátil con el que solía jugar, por lo que cumple los requisitos de sobra. Tendré que probar con el juego en CD, a ver si va (añadiré el resultado como adición al análisis). 

En cuanto al juego en sí: totalmente recomendado, sigue la dinámica TW de un modo más primitivo, pero con encanto. El mapa está dividido en provincias, agentes y ejércitos son como piezas de ajedrez, y la batalla tiene lugar si hay dos ejércitos enemigos en la misma provincia. Tienes una gran variedad de unidades, edificios para producirlas y debes ser cuidadoso con los impuestos y el orden público: puede haber rebeliones e incluso "resurrecciones" de facciones. 
No sé la de horas que pasé jugando a este juego, sólo superadas por Medieval II (después subieron demasiado los requisitos y tardé en tener un PC donde pudieran correr los nuevos títulos de la serie).

author: {'steamid': '76561198029033272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1448804432}
review:
Do not buy unless you have a retro enough computer...

It hurts me to say this because I love this game and I owned the original on CD years ago back when XP was the latest OS along with the viking invasion expansion. This game had a ton of bugs on newer OS's and hardware becuase it just didn't support the new stuff rendering the game unplayable for some. I was so happy when I saw this game added to Steam this year and I bought it thinking they have updated it to work on Modern day OS and hardware considering the system requirements on steam are Windows vista, 7 and 8 when the original requirements were something like Windows 95 to XP.

Anyway I got this game after reading steams reccomended specs believing it will work on my system...nope exactly the same problems as the original game I bought on CD all those years ago. Alls they have done here is copied the original CD and added it to steam and lied about the system requirements...I contacted Sega support since the game would not work for me and they told me these system requirements on steam are wrong becuase the game was developed before the release of Vista, 7 and 8 etc and has not had any updates since the release of these OS's therfore they do not officially support this game since I'm using an unsuporrted operating system for this game. The most they would do is tell me to run it in compatibility mode for Windows XP or earlier, which is unnacceptable since I already bought the game full price all those years ago, then read the steam system requirements believing it has been patched and bought it again a second time to find out it's pretty much identical to my old copy... sorry sega, but I'm going for a refund.. Please we just want one patch for this game which makes it support the newer OS's and Hardware.

I know some people have played this game with success still and no errors...but unfortunately some get these bugs like me becuase of the combination of unsupported hardware and OS which can either make the game unplayable or ruin your experience. Just keep this in mind when considering this game.

I would reccomend this if Modern day hardware and OS was supported and it didn't cosntantly crash or bug out becuase of that... even though I got it to work, I feel I need a refund still as the next Driver update for my GPU or OS update could easily break this game like it did on my last system when I got the old cd copy to work :/

author: {'steamid': '76561198085689125', 'num_games_owned': 1408, 'num_reviews': 150, 'playtime_forever': 3117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1321, 'last_played': 1711214595}
review:
Total install size on hard drive (vanilla): 2 GB
Medieval: Total War is a game I spent hundreds of hours on in my gaming youth. For the time, the graphics were amazing (and are still charming today), while the game-play was addicting. Up until a few months ago, I still had the disc version installed on my computer, and knew a number of tricks and hax to get the game to function without crashing every other turn. So when I saw that the game had been released on Steam with the promise of new patches and upgrades, I had to get it and see for myself if there were any improvements.

So how does the game run? Very well. Load times are massively reduced. Ten hours in, and not a single crash (auto-save is enabled). Wide-screen resolutions actually work; the game plays flawlessly in 1080p . A slight downside: the on-screen text gets REALLY small at higher resolutions; the game also ran flawlessly in 1440p, but the text was so tiny I was worried about eye-strain. Also strange: if you select “wide screen” in the options menu, the battles play out with black bars at the top and bottom of the screen. If you select “full screen”, the black bars are gone and the battlefield takes up the entire screen (which is what I wanted anyway). 

The Medieval: Total War is one of the classic strategy titles for a reason. You'll build your armies and manage your economy, while trying to establish an empire – one faction to rule them all! There are a lot things Medieval: Total War does that the sequels (starting with the very next Total War game, the first Rome TW) simply don't have. Like faction respawning. Think you've wiped a faction from the map? Not likely; the next rebellion  may spawn several massive armies in your heartland with a message like “A long-lost heir from a faction presumed destroyed is trying to reclaim his throne.” Even better, if a rival destroyed a faction, send in spies and assassins to wreak havoc and cause a revolt, in the hopes of the faction respawning in your enemy's territory, giving you the perfect opportunity to strike. Other factions emerge at specific times, like the Burgundians and the Swiss; each field some new troop types that cause a variety of problems. Putting an effort into building trading routes pays dividends, awarding huge amounts of cash if you can protect your trading routes. Conserving money and investing in the right technologies at the right time can produce an unstoppable army; spending too much too soon may give you powerful troops, but no cash to pay them. Loyalty will decline, and the troops might even rebel. Failing a crusade or jihad, or your king dying will seriously impact army loyalty - at least until the new king shows himself to be a strong leader. 

The battle AI is actually smart, trying to flank with cavalry, or keep you at a distance to pelt your army to death with arrows. Say you've struggled to beat most of an Egyptian army; there's just four more units located on the other side of that sand dune. Your now-exhausted troops trudge up to the ridge, ready to turn and run at the first surprise, and... those four units are all Ghulam Bodyguards. Well, you're screwed. Your own greed will defeat you time and again in battle. Balance your armies, choose good defensive positions, attack with careful timing, and send your troops in pursuit of a fleeing enemy with prudence. A sudden influx of enemy reinforcements could rout the units you sent in pursuit, which could turn the tide of the battle against you.

The Steam version of Medieval: Total War is exactly the game that I remember from before, now with faster load times and wide-screen resolutions. This might be my nostalgia talking, but the game stands as one of the greatest and best Total War titles, despite its age. Don't hesitate to grab this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133117633', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1448476469}
review:
Comme de nombreuses évaluations négatives avant la mienne, le très gros point noir de cette édition c'est le plantage du jeu à répétition en fin de tour, au moment où l'IA calcule les mouvements. Et plus on avance dans le jeu, plus ça plante. Parfois, en ré-essayant 4 ou 5 fois on finit pas valider un tour, mais c'est pour planter 10 fois au tour suivant, etc...

Ce jeu a été mon premier amour en matière de RTS et ça m'arrache le coeur de devoir faire une évaluation négative. Mais jusqu'à ce que les équipes de Creative Assembly patchent sérieusement cette édition, j'en déconseille fortement l'achat car, outre l'argent perdu, c'est surtout une énooorme frustration que d'avoir ce petit bijou vidéo-ludique à portée de clic et de savoir que chaque partie va forcément s'arrêter en pleine campagne, victime de ce bug.

author: {'steamid': '76561198261063112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3293, 'last_played': 1641028646}
review:
Primero Cabe Destacar estas Grandes Cosas que espero sirvan de ayuda a quien tenga duda de comprarlo.
1.- Estoy Jugando con sistema Operativo Windows 10
2.- Lo Juego con una Gtx970, osea una tarjeta un tanto actual.
3.- Tengo Resolucion 1920x1080

¿A que viene todo eso? pues este juego es famoso, por tener una incompatibilidad tremenda con los actuales sistemas operativos, puesto que el juego ya es antaño, (2002).
 
Parece ser que la solucion a ese famoso problema del Crash, en el mapa estrategico. se soluciona ajustando las resoluciones de ambos mapas, estrategico,y de batalla, a la resolucion que tienes por defecto en tu escritorio (en mi caso 1920x1080), tambien ayuda desactivar el guardado automatico, que en ocaciones era el que provocaba el crash, pero lo importante es lo dicho antes. Si ajustas las resoluciones podras jugar sin problema alguno, y el Juego Viene Totalmente al Español en textos. el juego es configurable a esas resoluciones y se ve basatante bien. por lo menos 50h, de juego y ningun problema

asi que es la oportunidad de poder jugar uno de los mejores total war. que hasta hace algunos años era injugable por demasiados problemas de compatibilidad.

Es un Juegaso y Tiene esa esfera unica que solo los juegos de antaño te pueden brindar. Simplemente en cuanto estrategia es de lo mejor que puede haber. 
lo juego con el ModXL, y sin problema entonces podemos hasta ampliar la experiencia del juego con distintos mods, cabe destacar que la orginial sigue siendo Buenisima.

Si Recuerdas este juego con especial cariño como yo. puedo decir que es momento de adquirirlo por que sigue siendo igual de bueno que en 2002, y incluso sigue siendo de los mejores, comparado incluso con cualquier total war moderno. Sencillamente un Must Have, de estrategia.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993781094', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1463257467}
review:
An old classic returns. Surprising, compared to other older games I have purchased for the nostalgia factor, this game still holds up well, even despite its age -- which is probably a testament to how great of a game it is. If you've never played this game before, you may be disappointed when comparing it to something like Rome II with its fancy graphics and tons of different kinds of units. Nonetheless, this game has a couple cool things going for it, including the ability to have truly massive battles (because of the limited performance hits) and some interesting mechanics that have been lost on later titles.

There are a couple of performance glitches I have noticed, and sometimes the game does freeze up on me. But it's definitely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007421356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1700951033}
review:
This game is unlike all the others in the Total War series, so calling it the best would be like saying an apple is better than an orange. But by the same coin, I don't think there is another game that I can say is better than it.

What the original MTW does really well is the campaign. I don't care much for the battles, as later Total War games have greatly improved on them (particularly the first Rome), so I personally never do battles manually in MTW. But the beauty of the game is that it is a lot of fun without doing the battles at all. I am sure that there are many who love the battles, which is fine, but this review is from the perspective of a pure campaigner. 

One reason you can skip battles is that the autocomplete is very fair - if you have the superior army, you will win, and casualties will be reasonable. If you have similar armies, it is a dice toss. This is different from later Total War games, where even a battle between 1000 men against 100 men needs to be resolved manually, because higher difficulty settings will attribute unreasonable losses against the human player, even though the battle would be trivial and boring to do manually. 

Because of the fair autocomplete, you do not need to do dozens of repetive unbalanced battles, which seem to bog down each successive Total War Game more than the last. MTW is much more fast-paced, and if you do want to manually complete battles, you can focus just on the interesting ones. If you don't want to autocomplete battles, then the game becomes one of pure campaign strategy, which is fast-paced due to the lack of interruptions from manual battles.

Adding to the fast pace of the game is the fact that you are moving armies from province to province in the same way that you would move around pieces in checkers. It is not as realistic as in later Total War Games, but it makes things a lot faster - no slow 20-turn marches across the Russian Steppes to take a minor settlement, as in newer TW games. And you are less likely to return to a save file if you get defeated, because you don't need to go through the same tedium again.

Another aspect that makes the game fast is that you can move an army from a province with a port to any province in the world that you have an uncontested line of naval control too. This greatly speeds up the endgame, and gives you the most tangible reward for naval power in any TW game. There are some kinks in the mechanic (I'll talk about them later), but it is a fun and interesting mechanic if nothing else.

Ok, so what I have gotten to so far is that the game is designed to be fast-paced, and playable just on the campaign map. The map itself has a very clean and attractive aesthetic for what it is, and I never bore of staring at it while I play. The music is excellent. There is a well-developed building tree, and a very good economic structure. It is balanced enough so that a good player playing at the appropriate difficulty setting for his skill will be neither too broke nor unreasonably wealthy.

There is a large variety of units that are available, though you will probably focus on recruiting a particular type of mid-range infantry if you are concentrating on auto-battles. This is a possible weakness of the game, because you are essentially building basic armies in the same way you do in Risk, since the auto-complete give little consideration for spear-beats-horse type combinations. But this doesn't matter much if you are not doing manual battles, and it is fun experimenting with the building trees of different factions to determine the most cost-effective and technically feasible main battle infantry to try to build recruiting buildings for. 

What is perhaps best about the game is that the weighting of the difficulty settings is done very well. An amatuer player on medium can probably complete the campaign in just a bit more time than an experienced player can complete expert difficulty. In many other games, increasing difficulty means slapping more health bars onto the AI, or removing your resources, or do any one of many things that just makes the game more annoying. I think (correct me if I'm wrong) that MTW simply gives more resources to the enemies, so that they can expand more aggressively. They feel more and more human, so it is more satisfying to overcome them.

There are some things about the game that will really put some people off at first. In particular, it is notorious for having a number of mechanisms that can put your whole empire into rebellion with little notice, especially near the end of the game. You will have everything in hand, then you will realize that half your empire wants to rebel (you hold shift for a summary of public order, and half the map has gone from green to red!). You try to settle things down, but a number of provinces rebel. But many of the rebels are not ordinary rebels - they are factions you have defeated reemerging, usually with 4 massive armies that are going to need a concerted effort to defeat. In an instant, all is lost, and it is frustrating because it seems random.

It isn't random though. An expert player knows all the tricks. The main culprit is usually your king's influence. The closer the line of communication between your king and a province, the higher the public order. Influence can take a shortcut across oceans if you have a pure line of naval communication. So if you control all the seas and your king is at a province with a port, there will be a big public order boost almost everywhere. But if that influence is broken for a second, everything can fall apart. If your king dies, the heir will pop up in your most important city, which may no longer be your capital. So if you capture Constantinople and it has no port, then your king dies, your heir will probably appear there, and you will have a public order crisis until you can get him somewhere better. Another possibility is that you start a war with a small nation that has a navy. Even if your navy is vastly superior, if there are any contested waters breaking your line of communication, expect rebellions. So if Spain has one ship in the straights of Gibralter and you have a dozen when war breaks out, you are still going to have rebellions at least until the next turn when you sink that ship. And since they might be building another ship that will appear next turn, or maybe the ship they have is fast and they intend to move it to the next province before you can hit it, it might not be so simple to solve this problem. You can also have the same naval problems if a storm sinks one of your ships, so it's always good to have at least 2 in every sea. A final problem too is that some factions have a tendency to split in two when an heir rebels, even if your empire is healthy, so you may want to keep your heirs in the same army as your king, just to be safe. 

The above issues are frustrating, but there are always ways around them. Some of them are a little cheap (I shamelessly go back to a saved game when I lose too many naval battles, because they are more luck-based, and I don't want it to affect the main game), but most of them are just being careful (keep your king in a good position, don't overextend your navy, aggresively take down nations with strong navies, etc), and there is a certain degree of pride when you can overcome all these challenges.

At the end of the day, this is an excellent game. It's challenging and fair, and it's one that I never tire of. I start playing this game again at least once per year, every year, and I am glad that it is finally here on Steam!

author: {'steamid': '76561198056627494', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1475658487}

A classic game that really helped me get a grasp on world history.

This is the Total War game with the best campaign map style. Because of the simplicity of the movement from region to region, the AI is able to cope with it, and offers a challenge, unlike the modern Total War titles. The battles look dated, but I still like to just play the campaign map like a board game and auto-resolve them.

review:
I first played this game back in 2005, and it still holds its own against modern titles, a testament to the fact that the core gameplay is what can make or break a game. 

At first I was expecting the game to crash constantly, just like it did back in the day, just after a battle or just as you're trying to save the game. 

So far, I have no qualms with it, it runs well on Windows 10, and I am both pleasantly surprised and happy that one of my all time favourites has made it to steam.

review: I highly recommend this game. It was what got me hooked on the series, and it still stands up as one of the best. It's refreshingly simple compared to the newer titles, and it looks & sounds terrific. It's a true marvel of the franchise and genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094630490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1420, 'last_played': 1697836611}
review:
Medieval Total War: The original and best.

Why? 

It's simple. Before a time when the series became so bloated and feature saturated, we had a game where every fundamental Total War mechanic was present and made sense. Battle map speed, AI and morale. Campaign map immersion, music, elegance and clarity. 

You can assign titles to generals and develop them as characters. You can manage an entire empire by dragging and dropping chess-like strategy pieces with maximum overview. Want to invade a region? Just pick up your armies and put them on the enemy's territory. And with an extremely satisfying "BOOM" sound effect too!

The AI works better in this game due to not having to manage pathfinding on a vast map like in Rome Total War and onward. If the enemy has troops in a province or attacks you, those are the armies you have to fight - every time. No micro stacks wandering about aimlessly. MTW allows massive battles to take place thanks to its very structure.

Battle mode looks outdated and clunky, but has several things going for it that other Total War titles often lack. Proper collision between troops means that a heavy and formidable unit can push back and scatter an inferior peasant militia. Arrows have a proper physics system that's based on elevation, line of sight and unit depth - archers should be placed in 2-3 ranks and given a clear line of sight to their target. 

This is on top of the atmosphere that gives the game an ominous medieval feel that fits perfectly, and that perhaps only Total War: Attila comes close to out of all the games in the franchise.

There's even mods!

10/10 a true classic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043904467', 'num_games_owned': 736, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1444629106}
review:
Medieval: Total War is an amazing game, but in the state it currently is in I cannot recommend it.

I began with no issues. The game runs well and is incredibly fun to play, but at around hour 2 I experienced a crash that brought me very far back in the campaign. Then I played more, ignoring the warnings I saw on the page regarding crashes. 3 crashes later and I can no longer ignore it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032278704', 'num_games_owned': 433, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1307, 'last_played': 1561480831}
review:
Świetna gra strategiczna, choć sterowanie i interfejs mogą wydawać się dość archaiczne, a "sprajty" jednostek i drzew budzące w starszych graczach łezkę sentymentu, nowym mogą wydać się brzydkie. 

+ Nie mniej, mnogość możliwości, jednostek, budowli i postaci zmuszają do rozegrania szeregu misji. Każdy kto lubi "pracować u podstaw" powoli rozwijając potęgę gospodarczą i militarną swojego państwa znajdzie tutaj to czego potrzebuje. 

- Niestety - prawdopodobnie z winy swojego wieku gra się crashuje na nowszysch systemach (Win 8.1 w moim wypadku) - i z tego co czytałem nie jestem w tym problemie odosobniony. Jest to szczególnie widoczne na dalszych etapach gry - problem jest o tyle bolesny, że nawet po wczytaniu gry od ostatniego save'a ta się wysypuje dokładnie w tym samym momencie. Trudno - spędziłem w grze ponad 25 godzin i czuję się usatysfakcjonownay, nawet mimo braku możliwości ukończenia scenariusza jako takiego - poza tym studio ponoć pracuje nad stworzeniem łatki więc może będę miał jeszczę szansę rozwalić potęgą Rzeczpispolitej Złotą Ordę i Egipcjan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008784471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1343, 'last_played': 1652511863}
review:
I've been playing this game since it came out, and I was extremely happy when it came to steam, "fixed" for newer systems.  It took me  couple of hours to figure out that it has not actually been fixed, as crashes are still commonplace, and gamebreaking when they involve AI moves that can't be avoided.

I cannot get a refund because it seemed to work perfectly for the first few hours, so leaving a review is the best I can do. I hope the devs fix the game, but it has been months since release and I haven't heard anything from them. Please save yourself the money until they fix it.

Edit:

All of this was true until Blandy suggested I change the resolution. Since then, I have been running with campaign map resolution of 1024 X 768, and I have yet to experience a single crash. To clarify, I am using Windows 7 64 bit. I am able to fight massive battles without any difficulty whatsoever.

review:
This game is seriously awesome. While it doesnt have amazing battle sequences, incredible graphics, or basically any of the things that are staples of 'good games' now, this throwback game has a unique charm that will enthrall you, and make you enjoy every second playing it. This was the first game of the Total War series i got, and hooked me on it ever since, as well as got me interested in PC gaming.

12/10 for me, a classic charm of a game that is amazing, and i am so glad they re-mastered it for Windows 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095684897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1459664348}
review:
Excellent purchase. Zero problems with the game. I just put the resolution up in the graphics menu and that was that. The AI is one of the best in the Total War games, especially with the introduction of the Vikings in Viking Invasion. The atmosphere is brooding and the contours of the land are very nice on the eye. The units look a bit dated now but once you get fighting then you forget that. 

You can easily get beaten by the AI on the batttlefield as you come across superior troops, more men, and crazy berserkers. It can be a little arcade-like at times with 300 peasants fighting 6 berserkers but you need to apply good battlefield strategy to overcome these problems... 

The enemy AI is very reactive - unlike in Rome/Medieval 2 whereby troops will just sit and take archer fire, in this game you will get charged off the field more often than not as the enemy tries to counter you quite forceably. Very good fun and every battle can be significant and is often decided in one moment..

PS The other great thing about the game is how you can fight two different armies on the battlefield like the Vikings and the rebels. Trying to position yourself in the right way while taking on two different enemies is really exciting. You often don't have a clue how the battles are going to turn out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010030185', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 22087, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9991, 'last_played': 1697947200}

author: {'steamid': '76561198124087444', 'num_games_owned': 393, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 14725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 667, 'last_played': 1696094167}
review:
11/10-Would buy again.  
Pros
-The graphics are good for the type of game that it is (considering the time it was made in).  
-It has great gameplay and an amazing range of options.
-The combat maps are huge(not the only thing that is huge, if you know what I mean ;)
-There are varied unit types.
-There are several factions to play as.  
-The massive scale of the battles make your wars feel LEGENDARY (like the ending of Warcraft 2)
-Like Warcraft 2, the game's strategy feel never fades.  That's something that Total War is known for.
-The soundtrack and sound quality are amazing.
-It's freaking TOTAL WAR

Cons
-It can crash quite often even with a higher resolution.  

All in all, buy this game.  Buy this game for your kids.  Buy this game for your wife.  Buy this game for your bros.  Buy this game for the random WalMart employee that serves as your cashier every day.  Buy this game for your dog.  It's that good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071041059', 'num_games_owned': 69, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1466127832}
review: I'll admit I haven't played this game much. But the game is so simplistic yet so complicated. It's odd, in Medieval Total War it seems Creative Assembilies focused more on the history and politics of the game than just battling. It'd be nice to seem them go back to these roots in their new games and balance out the actual campaign and the battles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995776049', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1439754661}
review: This game was great back in the day but it may not run well on your modern system. On my Windows 10 AMD FX-8350 | GTX 970 | 16 GB RAM system, performance was unacceptable. Battles hover around an eye bleeding 15 fps while the campaign map is between 40 to 60. Also a bug I noticed was that my unit icons didn't appear on their cards during battle so good luck knowing which unit you're selecting. You can see this phenomenon even within the sample screen shots the store page provides. I can not recommend this game with problems I experienced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009699375', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3955, 'last_played': 1567012546}
review:
I had problems with it crashing too.  I have a NVIDIA GeForce GTX 780 on Windows 8.1  About an hour or two, it would crash at the end of your turn, when the armies were being moved around.

But soon I discovered that it was only crashing with the default resolution, which I think is 800x600.  Changing it to virtually any other resolution (on the strategy map) stopped the crashes.

This was kind of an unexpected solution since I assumed the crashes were being caused by invading armies.  The reason I assumed this was that you could get it to "put off" the inevitable crash by changing your mind on an invasion and withdrawing your troops, or using them to invade another province.  After a while, though, it would crash even if you hadn't moved to invade at the end of the turn and there was no way you could delay it.

Over the moon that this game is finally available on Win 8.1!

author: {'steamid': '76561198109233713', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 6255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1702689440}
review:
UPDATE CHANGE THE DEFAULT RESOLUTION SETTINGS FROM 800-600 to higher resolution as this will probably be the major cause of crashes it was for me most computers are to powerful for the lower resolution causeing the game to crash.


Thankyou creative assembly for bringing this game to steam as was unplayable before on modern computers 
I remember playing this game years ago when it first came out this game made creative assembly it's a classic hit still highly playable today beats a lot of stratagy games on steam, when I saw it on steam I added it to my cart instantly bought it do not regret it playing on a 32inch screen easily visible ratios like it was built to be played on bigger screens.

Pros 
+ classic total war the reason why they were bought by sega 
+ good interface both on Battlefield and campaign map not like rome two or attilla 
+ Music and sound effects are nice 
+ Four Campaign periods to choose from all offering unique challenges 
+ all factions ulocked to play with there starting positions change depending on the period you choose each comes with a good backstory set up that adds to the nostalgic nature of the game.
+ surprising amount of depth from crusades, agents, family heirs, traits, rebellions, vast construction tech tree, unique faction units all descriptions, fleet contruction, trade routes, Historical events, disasters, you can even marry your daughter and son together through your warned of the consequences, long lost enemies reapearing becasue an heir escaped. The list goes on custom battles, historical campaigns, religion.
           All the ideas of creative assembly are in this game even if it can be seen as a little simplistic now the game makes up for it's nostalgic depth of character thats perhaps missing from games such as empire and napoleon.

Con's 
- Graphics are old now but suit the game
- Simplistic interface but suits the game 
- no blood and gore dlc wait thats a pro sorry 
- Maybe new total war fans won't like this game due to it's older style 

Overall definately worth getting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009250344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 642, 'last_played': 1457788139}
review:
My very first Total War game was Medieval 2, which I absolutely adored and got me into this franchise. As time went by, I started checking out Rome 1 and now, eventually, this. For its price, I think it's a good deal of fun, and there are plenty of features in it that I wasn't fully expecting to be there, given its age and how CA keeps altering features from title to title; for example, you can already ambush units on the battlefield and ranged units on higher terrain have increased range here.

The only thing that can be a bit iffy to get used to - other than the aged but nevertheless stylish graphics - are the controls, as you can't drag-select troops, placing troops on top of each other occasionally means you instead select the wrong unit and you use left mouse button both for selecting and giving orders like move orders. Another plus I liked, is the music and the battle sounds, like the screams and squeals in the melee sound like very genuine horror. I was also able to have it in 1920x1080, which is nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963514110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2087, 'last_played': 1689551963}
review:
Logged onto steam store and immediately screamed as loud as a thousand Vikings and plunged into a campaign.
[list]
    [*] Started as Almohads because I was so pumped I didn't bother picking a country
    [*]Immediately conquer Spain
    [*]Realized a balanced force of Berber Camels, Almohad Urban Militia, and Body Guard Calvary can slaughter anyone.
    [*]Forget that Horses are afraid of my smelly camels and Feudal knights get screwed by my camel army
    [*]Start to rampage through France but get gangbanged by France, England and Holy Roman Empire because I have slaughtered so many christians the Pope hates me
    [*]Force HRE to start a two front war with Byzantines and ally with the Orthidox faiths since the Ottomans blow.
    [*]Cross the English channel after decades and finally slaughter the last remaining French/English.
    [*]The end is near for HRE
    [*]HRE asks to ally with me, after decades of war I resoundly decline ignoring his pleas year after year
    [*] HRE gets slaughtered on battlefield randomly..WTF?
    [*]Realize while I was decimating armies all over europe Papal states became most powerful and technologically advanced army.
    [*]Pope rapes/pillages Egypt since I have no troops there
    [*]Epic showdown vs the Pope
    [*]After centuries I kill pope with 1000 catapults

[/list]

10/10. Greatest strategy game ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007246192', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1436496986}
review:
This ladies and gentlemen is the apogee in the TW series. While the graphics are yes dated they still hold up very on a 32 inch monitor at 2560x1440. The gameplay itself is something CA still hasnt managed to eclipse and that includes the campaign map as well as the battle map/s.
The atmosphere will draw you in like no other and the soundtrak is second to none.
And if you tire of the vanilla version you can always dl the Redux mod or the XL mod both of which make a great game even better.
Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007261127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1685371301}
review:
I've now bought this total war 4 times over the course of 12 years. (CDs got scratched up, lost or borrowed and never returned) That alone is a good enough idea of how good this is. Invested at least a few thousand hours over the years, and I can't say that for any other total war. It's no where near as stylish as the new ones graphically, but, that's to be expected. 
The gameplay on the strategic map is the best. Possibly one of the best ai that they've made. They will send a lot of assassins after your agents, sneak spies around and try to take away a general teetering on the edge of rebellion and make some surprising attacks. The pope is kind of , to put it mildly, the brown eye in everybody's rear. He'll excommunicate you in a heartbeat. The early game consists of mass stacks of peasants and archers, eventually leading to pretty diversified armies later in the game. The ai is prone to making "specialized" armies on occasion, however, in those situations they're usually attack with 3+ armies. The viking invasion expansion is a smaller campaign that's just as good as the early, high, late period campaigns with some different mechanics/building trees and some different standard of units.

Battle controls come off as aged compared to this day and age, but you won't be losing many battles due to clunky controls. You may run into path finding issues, which has always been a problem with the series for the most part. Seiges get epic later on in the game with you having to breach several layers of walls under archer/early musket fire. Artillery is really only effective during sieges until about mid way through the game when you start to get the more impressive pieces of machinery. Armies are generally well balanced, however, an army of gothic knights with crossbows/archers can just wreck face left and right if used properly. It can still be countered, just with a more specialized army.

On the modern systems, this will run quite well. I have windows 7, never had a problem with the disks and I don't expect any problems on here. I will say, 1920x1080 resolution makes the interface incredibly small and a bit laggy. Best off played at 1280x800 or so just to have the interface and text be able to be read without having to get right up to the monitor. If you played it back when it came out, you won't notice a difference in much of a performance from then compared to now. If anything, battles are more stable when there's 4k units battling it out compared to how it was way back.

For 10 bucks, you honestly can't go wrong for a great classic strategy game. If you still have the disks, buy it anyways just so you won't have to worry about it being gone forever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041924801', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1701217124}
review:
I nearly fell out of my chair when I saw this on steam. At first I thought It was my eye playing tricks as I saw it flash past in the Steam Store. 

I cannot recommend this game enough, and I bought it simply to write this review as I already have 3 various copies. 

While yes the graphics are dated and old, the game mechanics are just as in depth as any modern day Total War, if not even more in depth. 

At first it may seem more basic, but I can gaurentee you it is not, and it is setup to favor strategic and tactical play like no total war could hope to achieve both on the campaign map, and the battles. 

I'd pay full release price again for this game. 9$ is an absolute steal.


If that wasn't enough, this game is also extremely easy to mod. Anyone, even without any modding experience can go into the files and learn how to mod any aspect of this game very easily. I did it at 8 yrs old knowing absolutely nothing about programming, or making games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034936421', 'num_games_owned': 698, 'num_reviews': 381, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1674511279}
review:
I always like to start off my review with a story (generally); my current playthrough, I am playing as the Holy Roman Empire and I killed every other Catholic nation except the Papal States and he keeps warning me he'll declare a Crusade on me, he does. No one comes to kill me, for I am the only Catholic nation left; I laugh and let the Papal States alone to watch as I crush the small resistance of Spanish rebels.

Not much I can say about the game though, it's just a re-release of an old game, it works on Windows 8.1 as disk versions now-a-days do not (or have a very hard time to run). I haven't encountered any bugs in this game as people say there is a "crashing" bug, I've not found or encountered it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977357623', 'num_games_owned': 679, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 21, 'playtime_at_review': 1564, 'last_played': 1712258165}
review:
My favourite TW game. So happy to see it on Steam. 


Pros -
The setting is fascinating and really well implemented. Every faction, region and unit type has a unique personality that is reflective of actual history. 
The music and sound effects are pretty simple but nonetheless do an incredible job of establishing the setting and really add to the game's personality and charm.
I love the 'Risk' style campaign map. 
The core TW gameplay is as enjoyable as ever.

Cons -
The interface has not aged well, it's usable but hardly intuitive, hotkeys are lacking and WASD navigation of the campaign map isn't possible.
The graphics are obviously sub-par by today's standards, this is particularly noticeable in battles. On the campaign map I personally I think the muddiness of it all adds to the medieval charm :-p


I highly recommend this game, the minor flaws are completely outweighed by the huge number of positives. I have encountered no stability issues thus far but I'll be sure to update this review if I do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006679440', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 819, 'last_played': 1657919446}
review:
This was one of the first games I ever played, I have very fond memories of it.

Do not buy this game.

While the gameplay is still as great as I remember, the steam version has some serious game-breaking problems. Every hour or so, the game will randomly CTD (crash to desktop). While this is managable if you save often, you eventually reach a point where some action (be it yours or the AI's) will result in a CTD as well. Often these situational CTD's are unavoidable and happen several dozen turns into the game, rendering hours of gameplay moot.
Unless there is a serious effort on the Creative Assembly's part to fix these game-breaking crashes, I cannot recommend this wonderful game.

What makes it worse is that these crashes all seem to occur at least two hours into the game, so no refunds for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988438348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1390, 'last_played': 1550708399}
review:
Having played this game during it's original run, I was saddened by the compatibility issues following Windows XP's updates that made the game nigh-unplayable.  This new version of the game works flawlessly at 1920x1200, far beyond what the original resolution was, and still has all of its atmospheric charm as it did all those years ago.

If you can get past the dated visuals, there's a satisfying campaign to be had, and the battles don't have any of the annoying AI bugs of newer entries in the series.  Great game then, still solid now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076460674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1667652933}
review:
Medieval Total War premier du nom que dire sur ce jeu hors mis qu'il est génial , étant mon tout premier total war medieval a une place particulère mais pas que pour ça car voici les point fort du jeu.

[u]Point Fort[/u]:

- Les Musiques sont magifique et entrainante , a mon avis il possède les meilleurs musiques de tout les total war , les autres opus ont de bonnes musiques mais pas d'aussi bonne que celle là ,cela compense le fait qu'elle ne sont pas nombreuses .

- La Difficultés des campagnes et des batailles , les batailles sont vraiment plus dur (sauf pour moi :D , lol) même dans les niveau de difficultés bas , les campagnes sont autrement plus dur a cause de nombreuses révoltes qui s'installe dans le temps , certaine faction sont vraiment inégalée dans la dureté de la campagne ;).

[u]Point Faible[/u]:

- Les Graphisme qui ont assez mal vieillis (papier carton) , MAIS parce qu'il y a un MAIS pour moi il reste largement passable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991709351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1443475450}
review: Игра великолепна, тут без сомнений. При первом прохождении за Русь эпическая битва в течение 8 часов реального времени с монголами, пытающимися вторгнуться - это было нечто! Стал отрядами лучников и тяжелой пехоты на небольшом холмике, покрытом лесом, который защищал от постоянного обстрела, лучники стреляли в ответ, тяжелая пехота отражала атаки в ближнем бою, 2-3 отряда конницы добивали несколько расстроенных отрядов врага, и тут же возвращались обратно за ряды пехоты, чтоб не быть зажатыми в поле. По мере расхода стрел и истощения отрядов, отсылал по одному из боя и вызывал отряды из резерва, менял. Адреналин был такой, как будто реально войну выиграл!)) Ни в одном шутере или хорроре не получал такого фана! Фишка в том, что какое войско не собери - Орда все равно приходит силами в 5-6 раз превосходящими твою армию в числе, так и в качестве войск она весьма сильна. Но - ориентир по войску, которое находится в атакуемой  провинции перед атакой. Если оставить небольшую армию, в 4-5 отрядов, то Орда придет большим войском, но минимальным по исходному числу, уже не помню, 12-15 тысяч человек. А у тебя в соседних провинциях - примерно равная по числу армия) на следующем ходу в бой!  Но - в авто атаке по-любому проигрыш, поэтому биться ручками! И контроль, и выбор правильной позиции, потому что в чистом поле размечут все равно, плюс стрелы - потери огромны. А вот если все подобрать с позицией и контролем в бою - то победа возможна! Короче - рекомендации по-любому. А уж любителю стратегий просто мастхэв в обязательном порядке!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970631483', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1584129197}
review:
God bless old games :-)

Graphically - what do you expect? the whole thing looks dated and the "Doom" style rotating icons for soldiers may get on your wick.
Gameplay - Golden. Lots of wonderful touches that the later games under the SEGA regime could still learn from.
Music - simply the best of the lot. Play Viking Invasion as the Vikings - fall in love with the battle music. Sam Pertwee adds vocal elements so sorely missed from the later games.

This is a blast from the past that brings a genuine warmth back to those who remember, and a lesson in ancestry for those younger fans who never had the pleasure back in the day.

Recommended wholeheartedly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027029151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1498955744}
review:
Saw a lone Swiss King hold off a 1000 strong army of mounted Holy Roman Imperial knights. 
Killed the Pope with a catapult. 
Launched a crusade against Paris.
Had a king terrified of bald, bearded men. Later, his attempted assassin was a bald, bearded man, whom he killed with a cooking spit.
Brought down the last king of Poland under a hail of musket fire.
Desperately needed heirs so forced my last prince to marry his sister. 
Assassinated the Khan of the Golden Horde, causing his empire to collapse in its infancy. 
As Egypt, bribed the garrison of Rome into betraying the Papacy and handing me the keys to the city. 
Had a militia sergeant survive countless battles to become a one-man morale-14 powerhouse that could carve through an enemy spear formation like they were butter. He later became royal chancellor and governor of Ireland, married a princess and died aged 60. To my knowledge, he never did learn to read.

1000/1000 Best total war game to date.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960568549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 1638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1664782502}
review:
Pure, Distilled Total War
----------
If you like total war, but never played these older 2D games then Medieval and Shogun are a must try. Keep in mind Total War was a VERY different game before Rome: much simpler; almost board game-like rules where your objective is singular: conquer the map before time runs out. Build buildings in your provinces to get money and units, give titles to your generals to boost their stats, recruit agents to to your dirty work, fight battles to conquer everyone else, that's it. Very easy to pick up and go, and next thing you know you've been up all night playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094201047', 'num_games_owned': 1715, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1602960538}
review:
Best Total war game besides maybe Rome 1. Good ai, graphics though dated have that great nostalgia to it; it feels like EU4 with the total war simulation. I spent thousands of hours playing this as a kid. This game dates before CA began to fuck everything up. 

Even better, this version runs on later systems no problems. :) 

£6.99 is a steal to be honest; you get a vast amount of content. Weird to think how this early gem has in some cases better content then the likes of Rome 2 and Attila. CA, get your act together.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037787576', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1704053792}
review:
Medieval: Total War is one of those strategic game, where the aim is to conquer the world. It has the dated charm of the 00's and lacks the impressive graphics of later Total War games, but it is my contention that this game is a great one in its own right.

One might think that the only reason to get the game is for nostalgia's sake. And there is no denying that a significant percentage of the purchases will probably come from old players. The advantage of this copy compared to the old one that you might still own is that it is now compatible with modern operating systems (I personally tested Windows 7 and 10). Moreover, the price tag is quite reasonable.

The game is 13 years old and the graphics are no longer up to today's standards. They still have a certain charm to them and it does not prevent having fun at all. In addition, the game offers 4 different campaigns - 3 European ones, set at different starting dates and a viking campaign set in the British Isles, which allows considerable replayability.

However, the game is much more than just a means to satiate your nostalgia, which is why I spent hundreds of hours playing it in the first place, more than ten years ago. The game is different from all Total War games that would follow (only bearing resemblance to its predecessor Shogun), mainly regarding the campaign map. It uses a Risk-like campaign map, which means that movement is much more restrained. This allows for totally different campaign dynamics and really gives a fresh feel to the campaign, at least for Total War veterans who are not used to this campaign-style. One of the main advantages of this system is that it is much simpler and the AI can therefore cope with it significantly better than with the totally open campaign of later iterations. This makes the campaign both fun and challenging, as defeat becomes a very real possibility.

Regarding battles, the principles applied in later iterations were already present in Medieval and the most interesting feature is that there are lots of historical battles, grouped in different historical campaigns (100 years war, Saladin, Lionheart,...). Playing those historical campaigns gives a nice sense of progression and is quite rare in later iterations (Fall of the Samurai being the only later game to have a historical campaign).

After explaining the pros and cons of the game, I hope that I could convey the particular feel of this game, and I can only commend this game to those who want a different Total War experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561198050935851', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1435977683}
review:
Finally!!! Creative Assembly's best total war product ever (my opinion) and my first...

Although the graphics are....well....give me a piece of paper and I can make those birds that flap around durring battles. Still though, a very well-thoughtout gem of a game that can beat some of the other titles as far as gameplay is concerned.

Some of my favorite features:
The crusades and Jihads are massive
You freely give titles of lordship at will
Marry within the family
 -->  ACTUALL freakin' civil wars  <--
Somewhat more competent AI than the others (but I think it has to do with the simplicity of the game mechanics like the map being made of regions instead of a free-roaming world)
An amazing soundtrack.

I hear there are mods but I have no idea if those still work. Best place to check would be at TWcenter.net (HUGE modding community)

Best $9.99 I've spend this month...
